description: Really amazing quality sashimi. I nevwe fobto a restaurant twice on one trip, but thus wqs so good i wwnt back the next day. Highly recommenwd,,
author: David A.

description: REALLY disappointed with the size of the rolls. Total rip off!  We just ordered their sushi to go, and the rolls and pieces were tiny to boot! The sushi was good,  but one of the rolls had 4 pieces and it the pieces were the size of a quarter. I haven't eaten in the restaurant yet,  but now I never will. Thanks for the $50 sushi appetizer, I'm going to order pizza now.
author: Morgan M.

description:
How have I not written my review of Naked Fish yet, when I had my birthday dinner here (thanks JL)?!

I had ordered delivery from here once before picking it for my birthday dinner place after we discovered the closing of my original choice (Cafe Maritime) had recently closed.

The rolls here are interesting, not always traditional, but all of them pack a flavor punch. I lucked out and it happened to be a weekend when all the Marina-ites were in Tahoe, so we didn't have to wait to be seated and the food was served fairly quickly.

My favorites are the Fire Cracker balls, the Sub 1000, and the Mango Tango.
author: Dani D.

description:
Went for lunch today and the lunch special 12 piece sushi arrived after waiting 45 minutes.  I could not eat and had to go to a meeting. No apology from waitress or mgr until I walked out and sushi chef said we forgot to make your sushi. Note the restaurant was empty they obviously are not aware of their business. In addition CA rolls are made with Krab.  I will never return and I told them as much they didn't seem to care.
Lots of other good options in the area that care about their customers!!!!
author: shimmerSF M.

description: Been here several times, food is good. But, service was so bad this time after :30 minutes didn't even get a "be with you in a few," nothing. No eye contact nothing. Service sucks so bad, there aren't words. We just left. Go any where but Naked Fish on Chestnut.
author: Scott S.

description:
i was so disappointed with this sushi spot

I have eaten at the restaurant once and ordered take out once and both times were just lacking service and good quality sushi

The miso soup lacked flavor, the rolls underwhelming and the prices were a rip off. The spicy tuna tasted awful, the hamachi tasted fishy and the tempura rolls were all fried with not substance.

there are so many other sushi places around the area that are much better.
author: Whitney S.

description: If you are looking for good, consistent and reasonably priced sushi, this is your place.  They have great happy hour deals, and the servers are quick and incredibly nice.  Fish quality it good, but not knock your socks off good.  some of the rolls can get a little too elaborate with multiple toppings and numerous sauces, but to each their own.  Will you find me there for happy hour?  Absolutely.  Would a take an out of town visitor there, probably not.
author: Cat G.

description: Visited Naked Fish some days ago. Played safe and went for the rolls- Philly, California, Sweet potato (this one was exceptionally good) and one more i don't remember. Not too packed and we got a table almost immediately. Service was fast and so was the handing of the bill for which I did not give them 5 stars. Good place to go with friends.
author: Shruti D.

description:
Before I start I'd like to say that this review is for lunch ONLY, I have yet to eat here for dinner. 

My boyfriend and I saw this place as we were walking by, and being sushi lovers who are always trying to test out new places we decided to pop in and try it out. We were greeted by the chefs and chose to sit at a table in the back. Cute atmosphere, nothing too special but no complaints about the ambiance. 

After we sat down, a server brought is menus. OK, here's my problem, the menu was one page, double sided with maybe about 8 rolls on it. Whaaat? I know lunch menus are usually smaller but come on, there was hardly anything to choose from! And I was also disappointed since the rolls that were on there all seemed pretty basic...I read the reviews for this place after we left and heard rolls called out (Hot Mama, Autumn..) that weren't on the menu. Kind of a bummer, I wished they hadn't cut out the good rolls just because it was lunch! Unless there was a specials board somewhere that I missed, the menu was a little too small to excite me.

Second disappointment, I tried to order kampachi and the server said they were out and didn't usually carry it because it wasn't ordered enough. Then take it off the menu?? So then I ordered the aji and got the same response, they were out. Come on guys, the menus small enough and now the stuff I do want on there I can't get? Oh well. I ended up getting the tempura udon and an order of salmon. Boyfriend got toro and two rolls.

Once the sushi came, we were pretty happy. The rolls were REALLY good (dynamite something and I think sparkle something).  And for the nigiri...YUM! The disappointment from the stuff they were out of left my mind, salmon melted in my mouth and tasted extremely fresh, and toro was excellent!

The udon on the other hand was bland. I'm used to udon having carrot, cabbage, mushroom, broccoli, etc. in a bowl of big buckwheat noodles. This bowl literally only had seaweed and green onions, and the noodles were a lot thinner than the usual ones I've seen. On the upside the tempura it was served with was good, not too much batter and not too oily. Also, it was served with 4 pieces of deep fried gyoza, which was a nice plus!

The service was excellent, our server was extremely attentive and was constantly clearing dishes and refilling our tea and water. Our check was brought out on time and she was friendly (a grumpy server can ruin the mood real quick!)

Overall, sushi was good, udon was not. Great service, reasonable prices, and I'll probably be back (at dinner) so I can check out the rest of the rolls people are raving about.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Came here for Happy Hour...really not much to say.  

The subpar: tuna tartare
The ok: fried calamari, oysters, Hot Mama roll
The slightly better than ok: Crunchy roll

Hooray, mediocrity.
author: Derrick C.

description: My last meal in Frisco until I come back! I was skeptical going here, only because the night before was a full night's party! BUT I can never turn down sushi. I did not want to upset my stomach so I did not order my usual array of sushi pieces. I only ordered spicy scallop roll and oysters. Everyone else ordered sashimi and the fireball roll? Everyone liked the lunch very much so I imagined it can't be that bad! The hamachi was SOOOOO good! The oysters were fresh and delicious. They put a garlic ponzu sauce that just gave the oysters a burst of flavor! The wasabi was fresh, which tells a lot about a sushi place. I also shared a chicken teryaki plate with my friends. It was average, nothing too special. Next time I go to SF I'm gonna try my homie's place where he works! Good times SF!
author: Angelie D.

description: Had the Hot Mama and Sunset Strip sushi rolls. Both very different! The Hot Mama was definitely my favorite of the two (loved the sweet and spicy sauce). The Sunset Strip was different, fresh and a little spice. Only reason I gave 4 stars, they took a long time bringing our ticket and never refilled out drinks until after they finally brought the bill.
author: Heather B.

description:
My roommate and I came here to indulge during happy hour the night before our big exam to become RNs - the appetizers and happy hour rolls were delicious! We each got a large beer for around $3 each.. they served generous portions and we were surprised at how little we spent. We paid less than $30 for the both of us and left STUFFED! 

Oh, and we both passed NCLEX the next morning :)
author: Tiara H.

description: Sushi chef was super nice. The waitress and waiter gave me a hard time about redeeming the free hot sake offer they have on yelp. You need to know what you're offering! The offer says "excluding happy hour" and it's 1145am. ?? Also, I started off with 12 pieces of sashimi and they were quick to take my menu away like my stay here was a done deal. They didn't ask me if I wanted anything more to order. Rude, rude rude... Sushi and chef I give 5 stars. The waiters however, thumbs down!
author: Hazel H.

description: Wow. I must have passed this place 3 or 4 times and never thought to try it.  I went recently on a friend's recommendation and it was great.  My wife and I split a few different specialty rolls; the Sunset Strip roll was fantastic; so was the Super Dynamite roll (a spicier tuna roll that's been tempura fried).  Other posters are right -the happy hour deal is worth it. We split a few rolls and had a sake tasting and it was about $40 total including tip.  I will definitely be back.
author: David Z.

description: my fave go to sushi joint. i love that they use real crab and the service is always super speedy. great prices too. love.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I LOVE their happy hour. 

BUT, this review focuses on their Chirashi bowl, which is okay, I liked that they had some roe with the fish (helps with any additional rice), no special fish, and not a ton of fish (it's chefs choice), but it was good. 

Also ordered this dish for pick up once- I think I got more food when I ate in. 

The four stars- three for Chirashi, one for happy hour (which doesn't include the Chirashi bowl, but is so good for the Marina I give it a pass).
author: Xander K.

description:
The fish was decent, tried a selection of rolls.  It's more of a fusion restaurant so they served food outside of just fish.  We tried the yellow tail carpaccio as well which was a bit tangy, but unique.

The Cherry Blossom roll was pretty good.  The Naked Dragon was not so great, the rice paper just didn't do it justice, too mushy.  There were other rolls as well, but not too memorable.

The service was a bit bad, possibly because we gave separate orders to different waiters.  Essentially they lost our order and we had to wait another 15-20 minutes because of our food.
author: Kent H.

description:
Taking advantage of their 4:30-6:30 HH, I was pretty excited about my early sushi dinner.

My mistake was ordering three different spicy rolls without asking first if they use sriracha in it.  (I'm not a fan of it in my sushi.)  As I waited for my order, I realized my mistake but hoped for the best.

First to arrive was the Ahi Sashimi Tartare ($4.95).  It came with what appeared to be deep-friend wonton skins.  It was a pretty looking dish with tuna, tofu, and avocado.  Tasty and a nice treat, with an interesting textural mix from the tofu.

Next came my three spicy rolls - Spicy Tuna Handroll, Spicy Scallop Handroll, and Spicy Hamachi Roll, all for $2 each.  I was thinking what a sweet deal, until I tasted their spicy sauce.  Yes, they use sriracha to make their spicy sauce.  I was pretty sad and dismayed.  Sure, I ate my dinner, but it was not something I enjoyed.  

Sad to say, it pretty much turned me off.  And for that reason, I give it a three star.  I wasn't intrigued to taste anything else.

Happy Hour menu includes:

 $1.50/piece: aji, ankimo, ebi, hirame, hotate, hamachi, ika, kaki oysters, kampachi, kani, maguro, saba, sake, shiro maguro, tamago, tako, tempura tai, tai, unagi, walu

$2/handroll: CA roll, negi hamachi, spicy tuna, spicy scallop, unagi/avocado, ebi/cucumber

$3/roll: CA roll, tekka maki, spicy tuna, spicy scallop

25% of signature rolls and discounted appetizers (oysters on the half shell, ahi sashimi tartar, agedashi tofu, gyoza, and baby monterey bay calamari
author: Teri C.

description:
One Sushi deluxe platter, 2 specialty rolls, 2 chicken terriaki small plates, miso soup, and salads made for a filling dinner for 5 hungry sushi eaters.... ALL for only $82 dollars. Good service, chill ambiance, and  a dinner deal worth visiting the Marina for. 

Ill be back....  mostly to find out if the restaurants solo  secretive curtained booth is the real reason it's called, "naked fish" ;)
author: Caroline J.

description:
Since moving to the city a year ago, Jeff and I decided to go to dinner together once a week, and always try something new. While trying new things can lead to new favorites, it can also lead to restaurants like Naked Fish.

We showed up around 7:30 p.m. and were automatically seated- which was a perk. We got the table closet to the kitchen, which butt up against a three-paneled full length mirror. Who wouldn't want to watch themselves eat? (Saracasm) This is my pet peeve in restaurants- while mirrors make a place more spacious, full-length mirrors make diners self-conscious. Ugh.

I will tell you right now that I am NOT a Sushi fan. After a first date gone horribly wrong, I can't bring myself to eat the stuff. That being said, the boy thought it was great and would anxiously return for more. 

I ordered the Chicken Teriyaki. We also requested an order of Gyoza. When we ordered, we specified to bring the Gyoza first (as an appetizer) and to bring the sushi and chicken at the same time- as these dishes were to be our "meals." 

They brought out the Sushi and the Gyoza at the same time- which spoils a meal when one party has their dinner but the other is still waiting. By the time my dinner did arrive it was COLD. I don't mean stone cold by any means- but certainly not comfortably warm. Certain pieces of the teriyaki were cold to the touch. I kid you not fellow Yelpers.

If you're going to put down 50+ for a meal- GO ELSEWHERE. Additionally, please tell me how a Japanese restaurant decides that techno music and rapidly changing colored lights "fit" this type of restaurant. I simply don't get it. 

Needless to say, there won't be a second visit.
author: Annalise F.

description:
Over the last several years, Naked Fish has been my go-to place for happy hour sushi. I love the staff and the menu - such a great deal for really good quality food! I am so sad that I will no longer be living a block away - this is our absolute favorite! I always try for "the booth" which is my favorite spot to sit.

BEST: Hot Mama Roll is TO DIE FOR
author: Emily H.

description:
I'll just be up front about this: I am no sushi connoisseur.

I'm the guy that thought the wasabe was guacamole just two years back. Let me tell you - painful experience. 

I went to naked fish last night with some triathletes and I ordered the "safe" options: california roll and philly roll (salmon and cream cheese). 

Not having much of a basis for comparison I would say I enjoyed it. The service was on top of it with refilling my water, which is always a plus in my book. 

They had one booth that cracked me up in the middle of the restaurant. It looked like a private love nook for a romantic date.

Price-wise I spent about $14 on two rolls, each of which had 6 pieces. 

I'd go back if I were craving sushi.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Cool sushi bar and location within the Marina. I liked their specialty sushi menu and had a lot of fun watching the sushi chefs make the triple threat. But I ordered the 49er roll, the "Show me the money" and the Sunset roll. They also have a good wine list but had run out of the one I asked for. The waiters were friendly and there was a good crowd here.

I'd definitely go back the next time I want sushi in the Marina.
author: Tomas P.

description:
Two of us came here for lunch on a Wednesday and found the place completely empty at 12:15. Proceeded to order the ankimo (monkfish liver at $9) and two of the happy lunch bentos (chicken teriyaki + gyoza, saba + gyoza). The happy lunch bentos are definitely bang for your buck material but the ankimo was completely the opposite. 5 tiny little circles of liver that, for some reason, we found to be lukewarm. Meh.

On the other hand, the happy hour looks pretty damn good - $2 hand rolls and $3 makis. I will be by sometime between 4:30-6:30 to give that a try! Otherwise it's a pretty standard Japanese restaurant with pretty standard food - not surprising (I think the people that work there are Chinese).
author: Christina L.

description:
One of the better sushi places in the Marina (Zushi still holds the #1 spot). Decently fresh, fast sushi for lunch. Pick-ups usually done in 10-15 minutes.

UPDATED: Upped to four stars, consistently good and consistently fresh. Not going to ask much more from a sushi lunch in the Marina.

Prices are relatively cheap (think Marina + sushi)... 2 pieces of nigiri for $3.80, is a good deal... honestly a good deal anywhere in SF.
author: Ninja R.

description:
3.5 stars - walked by many times and somehow it just doesn't look right.   We got a parking space just outside on a Saturday night, fate?  Not quite since we walked through Chestnut to see what other options are available...until hubby said give this place a try.

It's ambiance lighting with the sushi bar to the right as you enter and a couple tables and seats at the bar.  There's a dining area in the back but we didn't see it.  We were seated at one of the tables near the sushi bar in the front.  This is a Chinese operated joint - the sushi chefs and wait staff are Chinese.

What we had:
large Asahi $6 - nice pilsner glass to serve it in
1/2 dozen oysters on half shell $9 - ok
ankimo app - $11 - medallion over a thin slice of cucumber with tobiko and scallion on top w/ ponzu like sauce - pretty good
Wakame salad $5 - not bad
Aji $6 
Hamachi $4 
Hotate $4 
Kampachi $4 
Amaebi $6 - head not fried long enough, not quite crispy enough 
Maguro $4 
shiro-maguro $4 
Sake - $4 
Tai $4 
Uni $6 - not the best 
Walu $4 

The waitress who took the order is friendly and can be helpful but she also disappeared after taking the order.  The other waiter just put the plate of sushi down and doesn't tell you what the pieces are - this happened both times. We can figure out most but just found this odd.

Overall, food is not bad, service is fine and very reasonable price.
author: Gloria H.

description:
***Good***
Sushi is great. Lots of cool roles and good options. Good for a date. Quality. Fresh food.

***Bad***
A little small. Not cheap, but fairly priced.

***Recommendation***
The roll that has the cucumber wrapping (can't remember the name). It is awesome.
author: Nick K.

description: I came here with a group of 7 last night after being turned away from another restaurant in the area for not being able to accommodate us. The sushi was super fresh and really good! Our server was awesome and continued to be helpful and friendly even after our group downed a few sake bombs and got a little rowdy. I will definitely be coming back and definitely recommend!
author: Dana A.

description: My favorite go-to sushi place in the Marina. The guys at the bar are super fast and friendly- love the Red Caterpillar Roll and the firecracker balls are a huge crowd pleaser. Also fresh and delicious at the right price!
author: Danielle K.

description: Had quite a lot of food, was nice. Definitely great fish. Interior could use a brush up.
author: Stefan S.

description:
Yuuuuummy!!!

I wandered in here the other day with a friend for an early dinner and was pleasantly surprised to find that they had a rather impressive happy hour menu.

My friend and I ended up getting quite the array of rolls and Sake while enjoying their quaint bar.  All the dishes came out promptly and deliciously prepared.  

The staff was friendly and attentive...the prices can't be beat...the quality was pretty high up there and the ambiance was the perfect setting for a girls night out or even a "date night."

I'll certainly be back!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Happy Hour @ Naked Fish Breakdown: 
6 people, countless saki bombs, full bellies = $108. 

Fish was  fresh, service was good, hand rolls were the best I have ever had... the drinks were cheap.  I think they brought me a 40... I can't remember.  All I know is that when 6:00 came around, I wished that I was hungry again so I could order more at least call.  Best Happy Hour I have been to in SF, thus far.
author: Roya T.

description:
Three years ago the food was addictive enough to coax my roommate and I to venture from San Rafael several times a week for about two months--definitely four or five stars. The hot mama roll and perfectly proportioned nigiri were the stuff dreams were made of. When I moved to Southern California this was one of the places I missed most.

On a recent trip to the bay I finally brought my husband here. Wow, what a change. The waiters were severely unhelpful, and didn't even ask us if we wanted to wait for a table before seating us at the bar. They seemed generally unhappy for us to be there. Were it not for the horrible service I'd have opted for three stars.

The hot mama roll this time around was good, but not as good as it used to be, and not good enough to require a return trip. The nigiri was the big disappointment; the preparation was unremarkable and the rice was dry. 

I guess three years ago the sushi chefs on staff here were far more skilled.
author: Annika L.

description:
My mother's best friend's sister owned this place so when I went, I got great service from the sister's husband.  My mother, her best friend, and I had superb, fresh sushi.

This was the first time that I had uni and LIKED it.  This place converted me...  A bit expensive addiction now...  Anyways, the fish was fresh and the rolls were a bit fusion.  The ambience was great. Decorations hip.  But come on, with a name like Naked Fish, it HAS to be hip!

However, the original owners sold it and since then I haven't been there but my uncle, who lives in SF, has and said it isn't as good.  So... who knows now.  But looking from recent reviews, it still seems great.

Their mojitos were great, btw.
author: Elizabeth A.

description: This place has a great happy hour! And it's available every day. The fish is fresh and their poke is really good! My bf and I go quite often. The one downfall is service isn't always great. They are hit and miss and can take awhile. We usually sit at the bar so it's not a problem but when you have a group of four or more - well - just don't be in a rush. We take friends here all the time when they are in town visiting and I think it is one of the better sushi spots in the marina.
author: Christy S.

description:
The older reviews really should be disregarded, since as of this year Naked Fish has been under new management.

Yay for free edamame!  Nice selection of sake too.  

As for the rest, the beef tataki and firecracker balls were very addicting.  The rolls definitely are more creative than traditional, but everything we tried was very tasty.  I loved the Sprinkle roll, Mango Tango, and the Philly Roll.  Ask the waitress about the sashimi, and she'll give you some good recommendations on their freshest fish of the day.
author: Joanne G.

description: Sushi here is really fresh and the staff is very accommodating. They are usually able to seat you right away, which is nice because, let's face it, having to wait for a table sucks.
author: Narina A.

description:
I have been here tons of times.  The people are friendly and give great service.  Honestly, happy hour is a steal here!!!!  It literally feels like you are steeling, you can drink and eat pretty damn good sushi for the same price as a salad in the Marina...? Not a difficult decision in my opinion.

Its really on the healthier side for sushi places, some of their rolls are wrapped in cucumber.  They keep things really healthy.  

I will keep coming back, thats for sure!
author: Alexis B.

description:
I found my new sushi delivery place! I've walked past this restaurant so many times but I finally took the time to scope the menu last night.  I'm glad I did.

The offerings are unique, TONS of variety, and it's not too expensive.  Warning though: this isn't authentic sushi, it's fusion-y and innovative though.

We ordered:
1. Superb spicy tuna (with tobiko, topped with more ahi)
2. Red caterpillar (spicy tuna + warm soy honey glaze)
3. Sunset (it's wrapped in cucumber instead of rice/nori! fantastic! spicy tuna + salmon + white tuna with a vinegary/rice winey dipping sauce)
3. Sub 1000 (I've now been introduced to Hawaiian Escolar and I think it's great, served with crisp fuji apples and a variety of tobiko that's darker than normal)

Everything was super tasty.  Beware though, they are not effing around when they say "spicy".

My only gripe would be that they refuse to deliver mochi ice cream.  Booooooo.

Update (1/19): they DO deliver mochi - i guess you just need to ask very nicely!
author: Priscilla T.

description:
NOM NOM!
I came here with a friend the other day after a mini trip to San Francisco. She ordered sushi (not sure which one exactly) and I ordered the happy lunch box. The teriyaki beef was really good since the meat was tender and juicy. The presentation was great for the inexpensive price and the place seemed nice and calm while I was there. (We were there around 1pm or so.) 

I don't go to many sushi restaurants because I am not a fan of seafood, period but I did enjoy my meal and if I had to come back here again, I definitely wouldn't oppose. Naked Fish, you done good!
author: Laura H.

description:
Came here with 3 other friends on a Saturday night. I appreciated that they let us call in and make reservations for 45 mins later, but once we got there I found the service to be slightly off. I believe our waitress mistook two of our orders but insisted that's what we wanted when she brought the plates over, and tried to upsell us on some rolls after we placed our order. She was kind enough though and ended up taking away the incorrect orders and getting us the right plates. 

It's pretty swanky inside and the restaurant was packed with your standard Marina couples. Sushi was decent - and I believe they serve some yakitori and other non-sushi-roll stuff too. I wouldn't fuss if someone suggested grabbing a bite here but I'd prefer to try one of the other swanky sushi joints in the neighborhood...or somewhere legit.
author: Krystle S.

description:
Hands down, the best sushi happy hour I have been to.
My friend and I went in there like a pack of starving wolves and came out perfectly refueled with delicious sushi and sake for about $35 total.... it does not get better than that!

Not only are the prices right:
From 4pm-6pm: $3 beers, $2 nigiri, $3 maki, $3 carafes of hot sake, $2 hand rolls and $5 appetizers. 
But the quality it awesome... the sushi was beautifully made, super fresh, and totally scrumdidilyumptious. 
Atmosphere is comfortable, relaxed and fun.

I will without a doubt be returning regularly.
author: D S.

description:
My girlfriend, Kimmie and I came here for dinner one night.  We sat up front and was wondering where everyone was.  There were only about 2 other tables of patrons around, but people kept coming outta nowhere!  Oh, there's a back area?  Got it.  

This place is okay.  It's a typical SF sushi spot with some interesting dishes, but nothing special.  It seems like it would be a good happy hour spot, but with all the great sushi places in the city, this was nothing special.  I honestly don't remember much of the experience...Meh.  It was forgettable.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Been here three times in past year or so. Service and food quality remain consistently good. This is a good place to go for a reliably good time, enjoying unique and "saucy" rolls. Dynamite Balls are always a big hit at the table. Prices are consistent with the Marina District. Party of 3, with beer was just over $100 + $20 tip. 

Do not come here with snooty sushi expectations. There isn't much "authentic" going on, but that's okay! I have always had a good time here with my friends. It's loud, busy, and comfortable. 

Overall: Good selection, good quality, creative, clean, with service to match. A "go to" spot for sushi in the big city. Solid 4 stars.
author: Jason S.

description: One of the best happy hours I've found in SF. Wait staff will come by and do a "last call" before it ends, which is great to slip in that last order you were debating about - which you ultimately usually get, because the sushi, etc. is pretty good, too. If the location was closer, I would visit more often.
author: Zach N.

description: I think this is our new go-to neighborhood sushi restaurant. The restaurant and the people who work here are welcoming and unpretentious. We sat at the bar and the sushi chef took great care of us. He patiently answered our questions about the fish and even gave us generous extra servings of the ones we noted were very fresh and tasty! He even gave us Halloween candy at the end of our meal, and we didn't even say "trick or treat!" What a fantastic Thursday evening dinner. Definitely coming back here and leaving a big tip.
author: Jen C.

description:
I'm one of those people who just never learn their lessons.  Like never bringing an umbrella with me when I know it's going to be raining.

Thanks to my lack of thinking, I was trapped inside Naked Fish one afternoon for about an hour after I was done eating, because I had to wait for the rain to stop pouring so I could run three blocks back to my car.

One star for the waitress not being pissed that we were there for so long.  One star for the relatively cheap prices for the bento boxes.  One star for pretty decent bento box food (the standards: California roll, tempura, teriyaki, etc.).

One star off for not having a large variety.  I think there were only like 2 short pages to the menu, and it didn't seem like they really specialized in anything (i.e. it's not a SUSHI restaurant, nor do they have amazing ROLLS).  One star off for being freakishly empty at noon.. that can never be a good sign, right?

Overall, this was a completely generic Japanese restaurant.  There was nothing special that made me go, OMG I WANNA COME BACK HERE.  So, I will pass on this place in the future.

Moral of the story: bring an umbrella when it's supposed to rain.
author: Tori S.

description: Great service and fresh fish. Try the fish tacos -- mixed seafood with mango in a corn tortilla. Yummy!
author: Sharon M.

description:
This place is always legit.

Went here again this past Saturday with the cousin after a long day, Naked Fish hit the SPOT.  We also got to sit in the secretive "king &queen/I'm really famous don't look at me" booth.....we had curtains and there were leopard pillows, if only I was with a boy and not my cousin! ha.

On my order:

Ahi Tuna Pokki
Sub 1000 Roll:  jalapeños and apples!  
Sashimi Combo - delicious
Hot Sake, Large Sapparo and share a strawberry-lemon saki drink (because they are tasty)

Now go out and have fun on the Chestnut bar scene.
author: Jana S.

description: 4 stars due to the awesome happy hour specials they have daily.  Oh, and the food is pretty solid too.
author: David P.

description: Not the best sushi I've ever eaten. Isn't the worst, but definitely isn't the best. The freshness of the fish is debatable, and the waiters seem to awkwardly linger/stare at customers. There also never really seems to be anyone in the restaurant when it's not happy hour.
author: D K.

description:
Their menu during happy hour is extensive, so that was nice.  Good price and good selection make for a happy sushi eater.  The fish was pretty fresh also, not the old stuff you get at some sushi places' HH.  

Wasn't crowded at all when I went, so unless it was an off day, getting a seat shouldn't be a problem since they have a back seating area also.  I'll come back if I'm ever in the Marina and craving sushi.
author: Jane N.

description:
Stumbled upon this place with my fiance for a semi-early dinner. Looked like a tiny place from the outside (could just see the bar) but there's a few tables and seats (including a curtained area) at the back. 

Ordered the tuna tataki salad and the scallop roll, both were fantastic - both had a kick to it. This with the edamame was more than enough for two people. 

Would recommend for a date, would come back.
author: Lisette P.

description: Great little place! I was able to make a last minute reservation for four people on a Sunday at this cozy no frills little sushi joint in the marina Labor Day weekend.  We ordered an assortment of rolls and nigiri, all of which were great.  The specialty rolls are good portions so no need to order too many unless you want to sample the menu.  Quality of the fish was great too.  Atmosphere was tame until a table started doing sake bombs and someone fell off a chair.  I would definitely come back here when I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Tanichka B.

description:
This is always the go-to spot for when my bff + co. want to meet up and catch up.

Items we always seem to get are the Rib Eye, Agedashi Tofu, and Hamachi Kama. Thoroughly enjoyable, way more so than the rolls that they offer. 

 Although I wouldn't say the food is exceptional, the service is always nice.
author: Julie L.

description: Great sushi, great service and overall great experience every time. We have made it a habit to dine here at least once or twice month. If you happen to be in the Marina and want some amazing fresh sushi at an affordable price then stop on by Naked Fish!
author: Jason F.

description:
came with my boss on a sunday.  plenty of seating.  took awhile to get waited on and with many sushi restaurants you really dont have one waiter/ress but get helped by a committee.

pieces were very fresh, and the 3 rolls we got were excelent.  Sake was very good as well.  

will go back at some point when I am in town
author: Dan L.

description:
Although unassuming from the exterior and a seemingly typical sushi bar when walking through the door, when I head into the dimly lit back room I couldn't help thinking what a perfect date spot this is! 

The sushi is fresh and the rolls are unique. Definitely try the "Snow White" roll with shrimp tempura and ranch dressing. Continue the theme of indulgence by finishing off with deep fried green tea ice cream, best shared and another reason to bring a date - even if it's your best girlfriend who's encouraging you to make your trip to the gym pointless. Delicious.
author: Nicole S.

description:
This is my new favorite sushi place! I came here a while ago during non-happy hour and the food/service was great. Loved the sunset roll, no rice and it was wrapped in cucumber, very good!

As for the  happy hour, the prices and selection are great. HH ends at 6:30 Monday-Thursday; and our waiter was particularly nice so our happy hour didn't end until 6:35! (hey, you'd be surprised how strict certain waiters get with hh time limits)..anyway, i much appreciated being able to order another $3 beer. this is now my go-to spot
author: Natalie J.

description:
I've mentioned in a previous review that there's a time and place for no-frills sushi, and I stand by that statement. But there's also a time and place for designer sushi. Naked Fish has designer sushi, and I am totally fine with that.

The menu items are expensive, but it's the Marina. Tough break. (Happy hour lowers the price a bit, though.) The service, however, is fast and friendly, and they seem to know exactly when to refill your water, which is a necessary service whilst downing roll after roll of delicious sushi.

Speaking of the sushi, the rolls are also hot diggity-dog delicious, so that's a good thing. I recommend the Autumn Delight, a tuna-based roll that comes with a delicious lemon dipping sauce, and another (the name of which I forget, sorry), that has APPLES in it. It's refreshing, people. Don't knock it 'til you've tried it.
author: Stefanie L.

description: Love Naked Fish! It's my go-to sushi restaurant in the Marina. Great prices (especially at happy hour) for very good sushi. Aside from sushi, I love their house salad and the firecracker balls are delicious too! There's also rarely a wait...
author: Katherine L.

description: Bad service, mediocre sushi! Long wait for everything while the place was practically empty.
author: ali e.

description: This place was pretty good. Couldn't help but compare it to my top fave spots in LA so it's safe to say that I wasn't disappointed but I wasn't amazed either. I wanted to try a little bit of everything so for an appetizer, I got the pork gyoza (a bit small, but had a good crispiness). Next, I went for the shiro maguro nigiri (loved it.. really good with a little bit of wasabi and ginger). Lastly, I just had to try what a majority of the yelpers raved about.. FIRECRACKER BALLS! Super yumyum!! Thanks YELPERS! =) It was the perfect kind of spicy.. topped with sweet and hot sauces. If I ever go back to naked fish, I'm forsure getting that!
author: Valerie M.

description: The waitress was awesome! Happy hour is great too! I'd come back again just for that.
author: Liz V.

description:
Ok, so I had my favorite Sushi places in the Marina, but in the interest of being a good Yelper, I tried Naked Fish.  Here's the scoop:

The good:  Great ambiance, and a pretty decent happy hour.

The bad:  Well, it's nothing special.  Nothing I had 'wowed' me. Also, we had something like four different people waiting on us.  One person took our drink order and introduced himself as our server.  He was quickly replaced by another gal, then another, and another.  Weird.

The ugly:  The fish were nude!  Totally NAKED!   Nude fish.  Weird.
author: Peter M.

description:
Maybe its because I had just gotten back from three weeks in Japan and walked into this place because of a group decision, but the food here is pretty average. The service is really really good though. We randomly got seated in a private booth with a curtain to block out everyone else. Ordered a lot of Asahi and edamame and tofu to start.

Ordered a few of the specialty rolls, they came out pretty fast, but offered little taste.  Had the spicy tuna, the baked salmon, and some combo rolls with eel and avocado. 

Overall, not great but not bad. Very average sushi place, with average price. You get what you pay for.
author: Jon H.

description:
This place is super cute!  My friend and I sat in the back, where they have a little room lit with a light-well in the middle of the ceiling.

I had the Dragon Roll (fried tempura with eel and avocado).  8 pieces for 11 dollars.  It was pretty good.  Service was pretty fast.

I would have taken off a star for the price, but I accidentally left a less-than-sufficient tip, so hopefully rating this a 4 kind of cancels out my faux-pas...sort of.  
(It doesn't get 5 because only the BEST restaurants get 5s)

I'd recommend this place for a nice get together with a friend.
author: Alison L.

description: Naked Fish you have done it once again. I love you for life, you are my favorite sushi spot. Fresh and yummy rolls, great wine selection and awesome service. We'll be seeing each other a lot :)
author: Kanwal A.

description: It was a Saturday night and we didn't expect to be seated right away, BUT we got a table sooner than we thought. It was really loud (people were having a real good time), which was good. Our server was very helpful! I had their caterpillar roll (not very special) and a strawberry lemon drop. I liked the place despite the difficult parking and noise. I'll come back one of these days to try their other rolls. For now, 3 stars.
author: Dàra H.

description:
We were here for a light lunch - which was good, based on the quality of the meal and service, which wasn't so stellar. 
 
First the service - we were seated fairly promptly, and the hostess was generally friendly, but waited a long time for our order to be taken. The tables and sushi bar were all empty up front, but the place was a disaster when we arrived - everything was dirty (including the restroom, as I discovered later).  They cleaned around us during the meal. Our side plate of eggplant was forgotten - we never got it, but weren't billed, so that was good. Waters refilled, teas weren't despite being empty early on. (2/5)

As for the food - four rolls: One hit, three misses. 

Hamachi+green onion roll: overpriced. Small, not a lot of fish, a tad "dry", couldn't taste the green onion - at almost a dollar a piece, it was disappointing. ($5)  2/5

Firecracker balls: disgusting. The worst of the bunch this afternoon. We weren't expecting deep fried balls (we were expecting that sort of light ungreasy tempura you sometimes get around the edge, like the beloved Futo Krispy at Moshi Moshi). But these were akin to mozzerella sticks, that gross breaded crust around the edge. And they were drenched in hot sauce, so you couldn't taste anything but that. Texture was mush. So flavorless, greasy, gross... ugh.  ($8) 0/5

Spicy tuna roll: OK, but disappointing. It wasn't spicy, and the tuna was just mushy pulp - just very low quality. I've had way better (both the rolls mixed "salad" type tuna and the solid fish). ($5) 2/5

Sprinkle roll: Excellent - thank goodness for that!  This roll had a ton of flavor, and just tasted wonderful. Great texture (soft avocado and eel, slightly crispy asparagus - but not too crispy) - would order it again, if I was to return... which I won't.  ($8) 5/5

Anyway - maybe it was an off afternoon, maybe this is just a poor sushi restaurant. But based on our lunch there we wouldn't go back - just too many better places to go to.
author: Jen D.

description:
Came here for happy hour and was lured here by their low prices.
$2 handroll, $3 for 6 piece sushi, $1.50 nigri, $4.95 appetizers and 25% off specialty rolls.

We ordered a cherry blossom roll that has salmon, hamachi topped with spicy tuna and bonito flakes. I like how they don't skimp on the fish. Pretty good and about $8.

Also ordered 2 appetizers of soft shell crab and deep fried oysters.
The soft shell crab was sad, there was no body! WTF?! The whole dish consisted of only the legs. Oysters were a bit smaller in size than usual and came with ponzo sauce. It was not bad.

Overall I would come back and try their other dishes since their prices weren't bad and place was not super crowded around 5pm. Although our server didn't come back to check on us, I could have easily flagged them down if I needed something.
author: Bunnie L.

description:
Good sushi, good service, very trendy.

Good for couples or small groups.
author: Harry S.

description:
I believe I am a sushi connoisseur. The best sushi is found along the North Pacific Coasts. I have tried Sushi in MN & NY, at the "best sushi place" and it tasted like Albertson's/Lucky's sushi...blech! 

I tried Naked Fish several years ago, during my ex-roomy's birthday. The sushi tasted like FOB (fresh off the boat sushi). The fish was not too salty, nor did it have a foul smell. (I have read reviews for sushi where the Yelper complained that the fish smelled like fish...like that is suppose to be a negative thing?)

What I have tried:
Edamame 
Nigiri: Hamachi
Sashimi: Salmon Sashimi
Sashimi: Tuna 
Beef Donburi Bowl

Rolls:
Sunset Strip
Fire Cracker Balls (my favorite)
Mango Tango
Super Dynamite
Naked Dragon
Autumn Delight  (YUM!)
Cherry Blossom (another favorite)
Red Caterpillar
Sub 1000 

Dessert:
Fried Ice Cream

When I say Naked Fish is the best sushi it means the prices are great too.  I don't worry about chowing down on sushi and then getting a $50 bill...it's happened before.

The staff is very welcoming. When you become a regular, they don't pretend like they've never seen you before.

Even though this place is a bit casual, they allow big groups to come in and have fun! (saki bombing)
author: Jessica B.

description:
Stumbled upon Naked Fish on a Sunday afternoon while walking around the marina looking for a lunch spot. 

Sushi was fresh and pretty good, but nothing spectacular at all. The service was great- very attentive and quick - but it was slow and pretty quiet that afternoon. 

The ambience is also nothing spectacular - pretty standard for sushi places. Good for lunch with friends. 

While probably a nice neighborhood spot, I wouldn't travel cross-town for this.
author: Cristina P.

description: We probably went on a bad night cuz we were sitted next to these loud awful people.  Okay they were there for a birthday party.  But lighting at this place suggest a more intimate setting.  Those people didn't show any consideration at all.  And add to that, I suffered from hives for 2 weeks after dining here.
author: Pam S.

description: This place sucks. Over priced and when they accidentally have our order to the table next to us their tried to pretend it didn't happen. I waited another 20 minutes after before asking about it and the table next to us announced the order was not theirs. No apology- just another 20 minute wait. And the food was only ok. Then we asked for the check and waited 20 more minutes only to ask again and wait ten more- they never apologized for the screw up and spilled soy sauce on me.. so angry- never returning! No customer service8( disappointed
author: Azlynn T.

description: AWFUL! I have been there 3 times and I will never go back again. All 3 times, they rudely turned off the music and turned on the bright lights when patrons were still eating and drinking, without any warning, rushing us out the door. When I asked them about it, the young waiter just said "but we close at 10pm"...and this occurred even then the owner was present. After spending $120 at their establishment, their rudeness is inexcusable and is part of what makes San Francisco a 2nd rate international destination...By the way, the owner and staff all speak Chinese, so I the Japanese authenticity is questionable...but then again they might just presume that non-Asian people just cannot tell the difference!
author: Sue K.

description:
After trolling the city for Sushi all over the place, we came across this place. Cool. Nice and busy, had a decent decor. We were happy....

Then we sat down. And look, I don't care about the two tables of faded college grads next to us - who am I to judge? My issue is that we sat down, waited 20 minutes for them to ask us for drinks. We order the drinks / food at the same time. Another 20 minutes goes by... food comes out, fantastic! But wait, where are our drinks? They were inattentive to us in the back. But what was wild is, they did stand watch, but didn't come around to fill water or anything like that.

The reason I'm giving it three stars is cause the food was pretty damn good. I had the Sub 1000 roll, and it was phenomenal.

Please guys, pay more attention to your patrons so I can come back. We were all starving / in need of some drinks. It just irked me.
author: Ward A.

description: My husband and I were very impressed with our meal here.  The sushi and sashimi was absolutely delicious.  We had spicy tuna, halibut and a specialty role.  All were great.  The wide variety of saki flavors is also fun.  Very reasonable prices as well.  We were thinking about going to a more expensive restaurant, but decided to try this place out.  We were very glad we did.
author: Shawna H.

description:
Price was better then expected. Service was terrible. Was there last night- 10/23 around 7pm?  This poor girl must have been all by herself?!! What kind of managment does that?!! On a sunday night? Jesus!! The place was def full. I had to get up and find our waitress everytime we needed something. She never even came back to ask us how our order was after she dropped it off to us. I had to ask her for water refils 2x. Actually had to leave the table and hunt her down to ask for everything we needed. And each time I found her to ask her for something she seemed so rushed and frantic. Didnt apologize for totally ignoring us, or not making sure we were OK. Just was like yeah yeah yeah, as if she was so busy serving the entire resturant. I feel bad for her if she was, it was busy. I wont be coming back nor will I suggest this place to any friends though. There are way to many yummy sushi joints that have plenty of waitresses/waiters ready to "take your order"  to pick from. Customer service is Key.  Sushi was good- service just horrible. 

Food was great.

Location is great.

Had a seat in the window. That was nice. 

Cool painting on the wall.
author: Jena D.

description:
I've been here a couple of times for sushi now, only on weekdays. 

I think they have pretty good quality sushi at reasonable prices. We split a bunch of rolls and had a beer each and it was about $25 per head.

The dynamite rolls were especially tasty, and I would definitely recommend them.

I'll be back for chilled out weekday meals when I want some decent sushi at fair prices.
author: Aadil M.

description:
I checked out NF for their happy hour special and was impressed. There is a good selection of items for happy hour including rolls, nigiri, hand rolls, appetizers, sake and beer.

A lot of time sushi places will skimp out on the ingredients for their happy hour specials but I didn't find that here. The rice to fish ratio was good and the quality of the rolls (taste and presentation) cannot be beaten for the price.
author: Lou T.

description:
This is a decent sushi place that I'll go to sometimes because of how conviniently close it is, but I'm a little surprised when I hear from other people who really like it. I suspect that it is because they haven't eaten sushi in the bay area and don't realize how good the average place is.  

I've ordered scallop that didn't taste right here a few times, so I'm a little wary of ordering things that aren't rolls or salmon sashimi.  When I ordered live uni, it was noticably worse than what I got a zushipuzzle, but they do get points for having that available in the first place.  On the plus side, they do have some pretty good rolls (unfortunately, the better rolls are the ones that are fried or covered in sauces, or both) and their happy hour deals are pretty decent.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Small and SLAMMED for dinner on the weekends, but if you make reservations you are usually pretty solid. 

Really great sushi and decent service. The service was sort of scattered in what they were good at, but it worked. They have a lot of specialty rolls, but they aren't the overplayed type - they were all good.
author: Christina P.

description: Excellent sushi... but I had to -1 star due to the wait we had when we got there. There were four of us and we waited about 30 minutes to sit down...at 10pm!  although to be fair, no one was really moving. This place seems like one where people really like to take their time to eat. I don't blame them... the sushi was fantastic, as well as the miso. Who doesn't love miso though right?? Being so late, I was starving, and this was so satisfying at that particular moment. Also had a great vibe, but that's nothing new for the restaurants in the city by the bay. :)
author: Courtney M.

description: ok so i have to make something right that i was wrong about.. i said this place gave me and 3 other people food poisoning but come to find out that we got it from the mass infection that spread thru the oyster festival this year. I assumed it was from this place but i was wrong. Come to find out that thousands of other people were infected with food poisoning from the oyster festival and there is an investigation being held by the department of health services. wanted to apologize to the naked fish for assuming that we got sick from there food. I was definently wrong
author: Isaac M.

description:
Hate to do it, but I'm revising my originally review of this place.. 

Came back a second time (this time, not for happy hour) and experienced sub-par service. I mentioned I was allergic to avocado, but she definitely didn't write it down on the order because there was avo in everything she brought out. They took things back and remade it accordingly, but it wasn't great tasting anyway.

Probably won't return.
author: Ami D.

description: Naked Fish is spot on three stars. Have been to the restaurant 4 or 5 times now.  Generous cuts, good portion sizes and overall good value, especially if you eat here during lunch. $5.95 for Uni, $3.80 for the majority of their Nigiri. Unlike Morimoto in Napa, you get two pieces too! The rolls are good sized and good quality for under $10 each. Did not enjoy one of the nigiri recently, but blame it on the fish, not the restaurant. Service was a little lacking, the Sushi Chef could have been a lot more engaging and friendly. The waitress was very nice however. Overall, would go back and recommend the sushi restaurant. Work on a more friendly welcoming experience and your at four stars!
author: Henry J.

description: I absolutely love this place. My sister and I do happy hour there every chance we get. The deep fried calamari is awesome, and all the rolls I have tried are super good too. Not to mention the $3 Beer. The wait staff is friendly and attentive. My favorite sushi place in the City!
author: Jenna M.

description:
This place is definitely solid when it comes to quality of the fish,  robata grill, miso soup and the various sauces that comes with some of the menu items.  The sake sashimi was some of the best I've ever had though the pieces were some of the smallest.  The tuna rolls were pretty small as well (I guess that's considered normal).  The veggie rolls was definitely above average in aesthetics, taste and quality.  

My only complaint is that the noise level in the main dining area is atrocious.  I guess they don't have anything on the ceilings to deaden the sound.  One loud alcohol fueled table right next to you can ruin your meal, especially when you cant hear yourself think let alone have a conversation.
author: Carla R.

description:
Sushi was ok, I give it 2* (as echoed by fellow yelpers) we had much better, esp in the sf bay area. We came on the GGB 75th B-day (Sun) and were in the area awaiting for the night to arrive. 

ambiance is nice. It looks cool and trendy. But we're more concerned about food here....:)

We arrived during "happy hour" and were given a special menu. The "special prices" didnt' seem that special. They seem comparable or even higher than other sushi places' any-time menu.  Had a sapporo for $3 and ordered a bunch of nigiri. They priced the nigiri by each piece (instead of a pair like other japanese restaurants. perhaps this is a pricing strategy). We ordered 2 rolls and a bunch of nigiris. The rolls were smaller than other places (4 pcs for the mango tango and 5 for the fried crab roll)...mabye this is the "special happy hour price"? 

I understand this is a chain...so I will give the Millbrae location a try next time.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
3.5 Stars

A neighborhood go-to for Happy Hour Sushi & Sashimi

*Good Food
*Great Happy Hour
*Chill Ambiance
*Fresh Seafood that's inexpensive
*Recommendation:
SoftShell Crab, Sashimi Deluxe, Oysters, Walu :) Fire Cracker Balls
author: Christina D.

description:
Naked Fish does fancy rolls really well, but the portions are tiny, and their traditional rolls are just okay.

I shared four rolls with two other friends, and we still had to order several more just to make a decent meal, so it got pretty pricey. If you like sweet sushi, the Aloha Roll was amazing. They also brought us a more expensive bottle of wine than we ordered, but when we pointed it out, they comped us the difference. 

The staff was friendly and accomodating, and the fancy rolls were good, but if you're looking for a normal size portion that's amazing and better prices, I'd recommend checking out Enoshima, which is a few blocks down Chestnut.
author: Megan S.

description:
I actually liked Naked Fish.  A and I were heading to Lucca to pick up some ravioli to make for dinner when we found excellent parking right away in front of Naked Fish.  They had a board outside saying they were having happy hour, so we stopped at the window to check out the menu.  There were a couple of items on the menu that jumped out at us, but we decided to take a walk down the street to decide if we wanted to eat out or just buy the ravioli and eat in.  Well, after walking down the block, we decided to go back to Naked Fish for dinner.

We were seated in the back and handed our menus.  It's got a dark, low-lit vibe to it.  My one gripe would probably be that it took FOREVER before our server came to take our order.  We weren't looking at the menu for THAT long.  Anyway, I don't remember exactly what we ordered.  I think we ordered the Red Caterpillar, Naked Dragon, some salmon thing with a quail egg on top I think, and pan seared duck breast.  I really liked the Red Caterpillar and the duck.  The Naked Dragon was just like any other dragon roll and the salmon thing was kind of weird.

In conclusion, I think the food has some awesome possibilities - I just didn't like the wait to order.
author: Kris L.

description:
Stumbled upon Naked Fish while in the Marina last night.  Vegetarian sushi that makes one full and tastes good is pretty hard to come by and Naked Fish had an interesting array of choices.  We tried the Spinach roll, the Veggie Dragon Roll (tempura sweet potato with grilled eggplant & avocado on top), the pickled radish roll, and the veggie lover plate.  My only real complaint is that the veggie lover, while interesting and worth trying, was possibly a little too sweet for me. Everything else was great, especially the dragon roll.  Craving it now.  

Also, a warning that the sake cocktails were alright, but also on the ultra-sweet side.
author: Kacie O.

description: The sushi was pretty damn good, and the food came out quickly.  They also have free edamame for every customer (bonus!).  My main issue was that the servers took their sweet time getting to me.  Once they did, it was quick.  To be fair, there was a big group next to me, but she said she'd be abck in 5 minutes, and 20 minutes later a man helped me while she stood near a wall.  Good place with a great happy hour, and I would definitely recommend that you try it.
author: Joe S.

description:
BARF!!!  So a friend and I head hear after a day in Main.  A small snack we figure and its Happy Hour! 

Woo Hoo think...

F'ing wrong guy!  this place is an abomination to sushi. Was a disgusting place. The fish had that thick too old look to it.  

Had the first three rolls on the happy hour roll menu. The Cannon crunch was bad.  Also had the hirame, fatty tuna, salmon, and hirame and tai.  Slices too small, and fish was no good.  

the tai was BAAAAAAD! 

I suppose its fits where it is. Even had some drunk Marinit claim to the enitre restaurant his friends Derrick had just arrived.  The worst part was my friend came from England for this crap.  

Do not go here no matter how desperate you are.
author: Spanky M.

description: Had a terrific Sushi lunch here. Everything was just right. Really enjoyed the 3 tier sake tasting.
author: Chris C.

description: Best little neighborhood sushi bar. I come here for take out almost weekly and they're super nice! My fav is the Fireball roll and the teriyaki chicken. The wait isn't long unless you go right when they open for dinner because of the grill warming up!
author: Tania C.

description:
Went here for lunch and got the "Happy Lunch Box." Came with miso soup, small salad, rice, and two items of your choice.  I got the California roll and gyoza (potstickers)- which I would say was not a very generous portion of 4pc. of roll and 4 potstickers. Miso soup was very good, and the gyoza was nice and crunchy with a yummy sweet dipping sauce. However, the Cali roll wasn't anything special. As for the salad-yuck! One of my favorite parts of Japanese cuisine is the delicious traditional miso-flavored dressing they put on their salads. The dressing on this salad did not taste remotely like that- it was very sweet and watery, just not good!

Service was ok...kept having to ask the waitress to refill our tea when there was only like 4 other tables filled. Ambiance was pretty nice, except for the draft being let in from the sliding glass door in the back of restaurant-which we ended up just closing ourselves. 

Overall, was OK for lunch, but would like to go back to try dinner and stick with just rolls.
author: Andrea K.

description:
I was really excited to try this place. Maybe because of it's very cool ambiance or the fact that I was hung over and in need of some substance. Yes sushi can cure a hangover, white rice is a great carbs to soak up all the beer for the night before. 

I have been on this search to find a great Sushi place that has just as good of a vegetarian menu as they do for regular sushi. I have yet to find any place other than Mobo in Santa Cruz. However their menu had a good selection so I decided to try them. I got the Spinach roll. I guess I didn't read the menu carefully enough, because it was wrapped in a cucumber and basically was a bunch of spinach stuffed inside with a tiny bit of avocado in the middle. Seriously if I wanted to eat a huge thing of spinach I would buy spinach. I wanted sushi! I don't get why people think if it's vegetarian it can't be as tasty as sushi with real fish in it. 

For me it was too over priced and not worth it. I give them props for their gyoza those were bomb. I might come back here for some Sake bombs and gyoza.. but that's it.
author: Danielle K.

description:
Their happy hour is AWESOME ($3 large beers)! And they are right next door to the Horse Shoe Tavern. Get a couple drinks and once you start getting hungry walk over for their great happy hour specials. They have drinks and sushi for cheap.

My favorites were the fire cracker balls, $5, (deep fried tuna roll with house trio secret sauce) and the Hot Mama Special (CA roll wrapped with Atlantic salmon and baked with spicy creamy dressing, finished with scallion and sesame seeds). The Hot Mama comes wrapped in aluminum foil and the salmon is dripping into the roll. It was seriously amazing!

I will definitely be back here for happy hour specials and they do happy hour every day!
author: Jackie G.

description:
Since sushi can be such a particular taste from person to person, often leading to bold statements and an attempted chopstick eye gouging, Ill make it clear what I look for in a sushi restaurant so you can easily figure out if you want to hear me out or skip the review.

I like my sashimi fresh, the atmosphere mellow, the service keeping their space, and the bill very reasonable.

The happy hour at Naked Fish is all that and as much more as you can handle.  Half price beers, $2 hand rolls, $3 rolls, and 25% off dinner rolls will wind up filling your belly for under $20.  There are a couple of great rolls, the Hot Mama and Fire Cracker Balls do it for me, but like I said earlier, their sashimi is so fresh and delicious that I pretty much stick to that.  Maguro and sake till I cant see straight is what Im saying.

While the sushi is probably not the absolute best in the city, its value is unbeatable.  Throw in a friendly staff that doesn't mind if you linger to drink beers and watch sports with the chefs and you get an overall solid experience.  

Come with your man/woman, a group of men/women, or even roll to the T-loin and pick up a tranny or two and blow their fat silver whore heels off.  Whoever you bring is in for a good time...
author: Brian H.

description: Very average sushi. I actually thought the gyoza appetizer was the highlight.  Wouldn't go out of my way to go back.
author: Priya N.

description: Decent sushi.  Delivery takes a while (sometimes over an hour) but good quality fish.
author: Jason T.

description:
Love this resturant.

kind of expensive (thats why 4 stars)

fun happy hour place to go with friends.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
Eh.  I've had better.  

This place is o.k. when you're in the neighborhood and want some casual, low key sushi...but it's by no means a destination spot of any sort.  They use imitation crab.  That should say enough on it's own.

The sushi is average at best, and same goes for the service.  There's always some sort of confusion with the waitstaff which results in getting the wrong items, or items that should have been comped (i.e.- sent back items) ending up on the bill.

Also, the crowd at this place can be very patience testing for me- either it's some marina chick blabbing on her cell phone or some baby bully Marina new mom running you over with her stroller...but I guess I'm the black sheep in Naked Fish/the Marina so keep that in mind...

Come for a cheap, laid back sushi experience... but Naked Fish is not for sushi connoisseurs by any means.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
My group just happened to stumble into this place right as happy hour started on a Sunday. Our luck was only just beginning. We were the first ones seated so things were running pretty smoothly. We ordered lots of sushi to share between us, and I couldn't name one thing I didn't like. We even shared the fried green tea ice cream which was interesting, but delicious. The best part is that we all left more than fulfilled for a very great price due to the happy hour prices.

For delicious food for a great deal, visit Naked Fish during happy hour!
author: Adiel N.

description: Good food, but very bad service!!! We spent almost an hour waiting for our food. Prices on a check did't match prices on the menu!
author: Olga B.

description:
I've been eating a lot of sushi lately. Not a bad thing, except for all the mediocre sushi I've had to endure to appreciate the good stuff. Like Naked Fish. 
Had a late lunch here on Saturday and was pleasantly surprised by 1) the not-so ridiculous prices, 2) the creative roll menu, and 3) the quality of the fish...really the most important thing when you're consuming large amounts of raw bottom-feeders. Ambience is nothing special...a long narrow room with a couple of window seats and a clean steel sushi bar...but the sushi didn't disappoint. It's certainly not the best I've ever had, but one of the better ones. Service was fast and friendly and they weren't chinsy on the portions. The sushi deluxe was not as filling as I'd hoped, but delicious and fresh nonetheless. 
It's a good lunch spot, but the lacking ambience makes it forgettable for a dinner date. Great for a mid-day sushi craving though.
author: Nique F.

description: Terrible inconsiderate restaurant. Waiting 3 hours for a delivery which was confirmed multiple times.
author: Antal R.

description:
This place used to be a favorite of mine until the sushi chef left a few years ago. So being that I had grown an attachment to the then sushi chef Michael, I couldn't bring myself to go back (Michael where are you!?!?). A few nights ago, I walked by and decided "what the heck". Maybe it's still as good. Maybe it wasn't Michael that made all my meals there KICK ARSE! 

Service was friendly, but needless to say.. I gave it a go.. and I'm not going back.
author: tessie n.

description:
A friend was visiting from NY, and I'd wanted to try out Pacific Catch for some seafood, although having never been, I didn't quite know how small the place was...theyd told me they didnt take reservations but the wait wouldnt be more than 20 minutes...
We got there and they said it would be at least 45, so we wandered into this place instead.

The decor was cute, but the service was god awful...we had to wait forever just to catch someone to explain to us what half the nigiri were..and had we ordered more than one item each i'm pretty sure we wouldnt ever have seen them..

i think i got the ahi tuna dish, which was small but decently priced (i wanted sashimi but for $9.5 for 5 pieces it seemed a rip off...the sampler one sounded great but not for $23, is there no portion size in between the two?!), my friend got a roll, i believe the caterpillar...basically both were nothing special but not poor, nice location, although due to the service and portion size i dont think i'll be back...i did hear wasabi across the street is better!
author: Danielle J.

description:
I love to eat sushi, but not at the cost of bad service.  We went in here with a group of 7 people during fleet week and the service was horrible.  We walked in at 5:45 pm and the main chef behind the bar tells us we only have 5 minutes till happy hour is over.  We say ok, can we have a seat?  He says, it's unlikely you're going to get a seat before happy hour is over.  Fortunately we DO get a seat.  Unfortunately, I saw him run over to our server/host and tell them we're past the HH time.  We look at our watch and it's only 5:50 pm.  We sit for another 5 minutes and the gal comes over to tell us HH is over.  I inform her that we've been patiently waiting for 10 minutes for menus.  She says, we've been informed that HH is cut off in the kitchen.  Horrible!

We live in the Marina and eat out quite often.  We love sushi, but will have to hold off going to what used to be our favorite sushi place, Naked Fish.  It's sad that they feel the need to be rude rather than helpful to customers.  Long after the rush of fleet week, we will continue to pass this place by and so will all my friends.  No one will want to eat at a place that practices rudeness like this.
author: Malisa S.

description:
While most of you like to celebrate TACO Tuesdays, the BF and I celebrate TAKO Tuesdays. Tako as in fresh octopus. And being that we've come up with this ritual where we're not allowed to eat at the same restaurant more than once, we've been able to try tako from a multitude of places. Most recently, Naked Fish definitely wins the lead for having the best takos so far.

We came into Naked Fish during their happy hour. Their deals weren't too shabby. We ordered 4 pieces of tako nigiri which were $1.50 each, fried oysters, fried soft shell crab, the Golden Gate Rainbow and the Autumn Delight. The tako nigiri was definitely my favorite out of all the dishes. This actually was my first time trying tako nigiri, since we usually order tako sashimi, but I absolutely loved the tako in nigiri form. It tasted so fresh and didn't have that Ocean beach salt water fishy dead whale aftertaste. It was light and refreshing, yet sweet and flavorful. The Golden Gate Rainbow was my second favorite dish. It wasn't anything special, just the usual California roll topped with raw fish. I usually try to stay away from the California roll since it's so amateur when eating sushi, but I suppose when raw fish is included in the picture, I tend to let California roll bigones be bigones. As for the fried oysters and fried soft shell crab... mehhh tell me something new. It was the usual fried crispy appetizer filler that you can get at any cheap hole in the wall restaurant and still have it taste exactly the same as it did in Naked Fish. However, the Autumn Delight, now this dish was horrible. I'm starting to think any type of food ending with the word delight is pure crap (eg. Sunny Delight, now that is thee most worst tasting self proclaimed delight of all time... OF ALL TIME!) The Autumn Delight was so bland and the slightly fried tuna and albacore combo tasted like a soggy wet blank every time it hung out in my mouth. Their lemon ponzu only added on to that soggy wet blanket taste since it basically was a watery tasteless sauce infested with unnecessary sesame seeds. And lastly, I hate wasabi, so being that the wasabi mayo was the Autumn Delight's last chance for approval definitely didn't save it from it's failing reputation.

Whatever. I still like their happy hour deals and definitely wouldn't mind frequenting this spot just to get my tako fix in.
author: Ally C.

description: We ordered sushi delivery tonight, a Thursday at 8:30pm. It states that it will take 45 mins to 1 hour for delivery. After an hour and 40 minutes, I tried calling to find out what happened, and cancel our order. No answer. We are now going to bed without dinner and no idea what we just paid over 50$ for. Note: The food arrived 2 hours late. And the icing on the cake? No wasabe or ginger. Really?? I will call and speak with "Chris" the manager tomorrow. The delivery man had nothing to say. Another time I ordered from them and the food was almost 2 hours late, and cold - specifically, some of the rolls are made to be hot, or at least warm, and once they cool they are soggy and inedible. I live about 5 mins from the restaurant so there is no excuse. They just showed up, TWO hours LATE! This is absolutely insane and not acceptable of ANY restaurant. There are about 1000 sushi places in the city so somewhere that is this neglectful, irresponsible, and inconsiderate of their customers does NOT deserve my, our your business.
author: Jessica S.

description: Best Happy Hour in town. You can't beat $3 beers accomodated with $3 rolls and $2 hand rolls.
author: Corey R.

description: Best Happy Hour in the Marina! Consistently good sushi at a GREAT price.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
I don't eat seafood, but I will appreciate a Japanese restaurant for it's meat dishes and veggie rolls...

Of the entrees, I highly recommend the Kiwi Steak. I would revisit Naked Sushi for this dish alone -- and for the tasty strawberry lemon drop! Unfortunately, I also ordered a disgusting veggie roll. Bleh.

Overall, Naked Sushi is A-OK. It's a good place to get your munchies on before going to the bars/clubs on Chestnut. It's relatively inexpensive and does not have a wait on Friday/Saturday nights, even during peak dinner hours.
author: Han C.

description:
So I was trying to go to my favorite Zushi Puzzle last week but seems like they were closed for an extended holiday (now back). As a result, to satiate our sushi craving, my friends and I opted to try Naked Fish, since we had heard some good things about the place.

We were seated promptly (there is a smallish but fun bar up front, dining in the back), and had our drink orders taken right away. Our waitress was ok, but the fish she served us was pretty darn fresh and good. 

Naked Fish's fish arrives via Fed Ex from Hawaii, so make sure to try the Hawaiian varieties they have on special. We were also quite pleased with some of their rolls like Autumn Delight and Tokyo Breeze (not to be confused with Drift). Their Spicy Tuna is called, "Outstandng Spicy Tuna," as if you'd expect anything less, but I find this wording to somehow explain why I like this place and will be there more often when galavanting in the Marina.

If you go around happy hour, glasses of beer and wine are half off, woohoo!
author: Nish N.

description:
They so wanted to be the next ultra-hip Mas Sake or Ace Wasabi, but fell short.

I agree with the yelp masses, decent rolls, moderate price.

"Happy Hour" is a rip-off. 25% off $10 rolls that are super tiny?!

Their idea of creative rolls means no rice, no nori, and oddly sweetened sauce...
I asked for wasabi since my roll didn't come with any, and the waitress gave me an odd stare down, like she had something better to do, in the half empty joint on a Tuesday early evening.  This seems to happen repeatedly, even though I tip well, and always try to be friendly.

Neither ultra hip, nor friendly neighborhood joint. Somewhere in the mediocre middle.
author: Bamboo T.

description:
Come for happy hour.... I repeat, happy hour. 

That is all....

Oh, and eat a fried ice cream....
author: Tiffany L.

description:
It's a cute place very inviting atmosphere. The food was great with a unique presentation. The wait staff were great! It's a bit loud however worth going! I didn't partake of the Sake but I did read the Sake list and was impressed by the variety.

I had a Rock N Roll Sushi roll and Seaweed Salad
author: Christina K.

description:
UGH. Thumping music, flashing lights, really echoey (not a word) rooms, and bad sushi with embarrassingly over-the-top names like "Sub 1000" (cue dramatic music). Try going out to dinner with people you've just met here.

Example snatch of conversation:
Me: So where did you *thump* go to school?
New Friend: I went to *thump*.
Me: Where?
NF: *thump thump thump*
Me: Ohh. (????) Cool.
NF: How about you? (or at least I think she said that)
Me: Whoa, did the lights just change color? 
NF: I'm blind! I'm blind!
Me: What?!?

So above conversation might be exaggerated, but only to prove a point. 

The sushi was bad, I mean chewy and flavorless and the atmosphere blows. They even fucked up the Miso! How do you even do that? 2 stars for the Sake Mojitos.
author: Ali L.

description: I've been here for lunch and for happy hour and I've been very please both times!  Their happy hour specials are amazing!!  And they have a super cheap bento box lunch for only like $8 that is very filling!  I have recommended this place to a lot of my coworkers and friends.
author: Sintia M.

description:
Can't complain about lunch for two with a bill under $20.

The food was decent, but nothing to write home about. I got the salmon teriyaki with california rolls combo, and unfortunately, left the restaurant still a bit hungry.
author: Carolynne R.

description:
Ambiance and service are nothing to write home about, but the sushi quality is out of this world.  I eat here at 1x a week (I recommend sitting at the sushi bar).  I order the sashimi- the salmon, yellowtail, walu, tuna - all of it is SO, SO fresh (and huge pieces). Get the sashimi sampler platter - it's around $20 and comes with 15 -18 large pieces of fresh sashimi. Good bang for the buck here.  (I don't do rolls so not sure about those. But, if you like just straight fish - you found your place).   

Note: Happy hour is amazing - great deals on sushi and beer.
author: Brooke S.

description:
Naked Fish is by far my favorite Sushi place. There food is delicious and service is quick and the waiters are very professional. The interior is modern, comfortable, and stylish. I love their spider and dragon rolls, and the beef teriyaki is delicious. 

I highly recommend this sushi place.

Oh yea they have really yummy cocktails ;)
author: Inna R.

description: I'm pretty sure the people who run this Japanese restaurant are Chinese, and while that isn't always a bad thing, it is in this particular instance. I went in during the week for the lunch menu (which doesn't run on the weekends, so take note) and I had the large nigiri special. The fish had a funky quality. It wasn't quite bad, but it seemed to have this vague refrigerator smell that really ruined it for me. Plus even though it was a deluxe set, he gave me 2 pieces each of pretty standard and boring fish-- not one piece of each variety and definitely not what is considered deluxe fish in other restaurants, I don't think I'll be back.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
Their happy hour is great from 430-630 M-Th their hand rolls are $2, their maki rolls are $3, they have $5 buck appetizers and it's good! The sushi is pretty darn fresh and pretty damn good.
You get seated promptly, they take a bit to get the order and serve it sometimes but no big deal. If I am thinking about sushi and its at all near their happy hour I am there.. or even a pick me up. I mean really you can get quite filled on under $20 there.
author: Natasha M.

description: Always good service and great happy hour!! Super fresh tasting fish always. We find ourselves here about once a week!
author: Scott L.

description:
A girlfriend and I ate lunch here last month. Two MILF's out on the town up to no good as usual, spending lots of our hubbies money. Ok, well not really but it sounded good. 

Anyway, after asking like 5 people on the street where a good sushi place was a nice woman suggested Naked Fish. My bff and I were so glad we went here because it was delicious!
