I suggest the Red Catapillar roll! Super good! I think we also had a roll called "Show me the money" and that was good too. I might have made that name up but the roll was delicious. 

The waiter was really nice and attentive. 

I would definitely go back here!
author: lisa h.

description:
I've been to almost every sushi restaurant in the Marina/ Cow Hollow area.  Zushi Puzzle was once my favorite (food, not service) - but Naked Fish has taken over with slightly better service and much better food.  

Their rolls are unique and the fish is some of the best quality in the neighborhood.
author: Alison W.

description: Five pieces of  toro sashimi (FATTY TUNA) for $25 is a pretty good price, but I prefer my meats fattier. I mean tuna. I prefer my fatty tuna fattier is what I meant. Fatter.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Terrible place - reminds of a cheap Chinese restaurant. We ordered their Udon and it was truly unpalatable. When we told the waitress it was awful she did not apologize just brought the bill with Udon still on it. 
Really with so many great sushi places to choose avoid this place.
author: Lana V.

description:
Here's the short and skinny on Naked Fish: I've had better, I've had worse. It's ok, but they have room for improvement.

Nigiri: quality tends to be decent to good. However, I think last night the regular sushi guy must have had the night off and his apprentice stepped in, because some of our cuts still had fish skin on it when they most clearly should not have. Sometimes the toro is better than others - a month ago it was dreamily great, last night it was a bit tough. I had to wonder if that was just chance, or indicative of a trend.

Rolls: Skip the designer rolls. We've had nothing but bad luck with the rolls here - we've tried 3-4 different rolls on three occasions over a few months, and we both agree that rolls are not this place's forte. 

Service: Varies. I've had great to mediocre service here. Staff has ranged from knowledgeable to first-day-on-the-job. Your mileage may vary. At the moment, there's one *very* cute lady working here, very friendly, very efficient, very helpful. Although I was a bit miffed when she indicated it was "last call" at 9pm (it was NYE, after all), then saw a new couple being seated 15 minutes later. Hmmm. It didn't effect us, but I did feel as if I was being a bit rushed out the door so the staff could hit a NYE party. (That's speculation, but it is a vibe that a staffer left with me, a customer, so it counts in a review.) We were given a mini-bottle of Brut on the house, which was a very nice touch, and one we both appreciated a lot. Thanks for that! :)

Atmosphere: It's trendy and comfortable with an ambient/low-key techno vibe. It's clear they're trying to make it nice on a budget. But in the end, I go to a sushi place seeking mind-bending nigiri that makes me cry, not atmosphere.

The staff is mostly Cantonese-speaking Chinese, so if you're expecting a die-hard authentic Japanese through-and-through sushi place, Naked Fish is not that place. But for a decent local sushi joint, it'll do. It's not as good as the original sushi place that was in this same space in the late '90s - that place was definitely more downscale and lowkey, but it had phenominal sushi.

At the end of the day, what makes me happy is great sushi and a good price. Everything else is secondary. Naked Fish does alright, but it's not the dream-sushi place I'm still searching for.
author: Gregg G.

description:
I originally gave Naked Fish 3 stars but I've changed my mind. We went there for happy hour and in spite of the extreme noisiness, we had a great dinner.

We took advantage of the happy hour discount on special rolls and got to sample some really delicious and inventive selections including one that was rolled in very thinly sliced cucumber with mango. Mmmm!!

With a carafe of sake, this was the perfect way to wind down after a long week.
author: N J.

description:
Your average sushi restaurant, but it does have some relatively good deals during happy hour.  We dropped in after the Union Street Festival for something light and relatively low-key, and that is exactly what we got.

During happy hour, the fancier rolls (i.e. sunset roll, rainbow rolls, etc.) are 25% off, small rolls (i.e. tuna roll, hamachi roll, etc.) are $3.00 , nigiri  is $1.50, and hand rolls are $2.00. 

I don't really have any rolls to recommend, since none really impressed me. The rolls are small, the fish mediocre, and I felt like the rice was not pressed tightly enough when they made the rolls. The sun set strip we ordered, which is a roll consisted of tuna, yellowtail, minced salmon, and avocado wrapped in cucumber with no rice and soaked in vinegar was disappointing. It came with only 4 pieces and one of the pieces was missing avocado, again, demonstrating the sushi chef's lack of focus and precision.  I did, however, enjoy the spicy scallop hand roll, but it was pretty standard and nothing to get excited about either. 

The service here is a bit under par. The waitresses were not rude, but they also didn't pay a whole lot of attention to our table. 

All in all, it was not a terrible experience, but nothing here compels me to return again.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Really only 3.5 stars. 

Went there for lunch. Decor was find, typical Japanese, nothing that stands out to me.  Service was fine though; it was busy but there were a few open tables so maybe that helped the service levels, who knows?

Menu looked good, they had some creative appetizers listed though I did not get to try them.  Had the Naked Roll which was different but good.  The Dynamite Roll was good but the fish was raw on one side and cooked on another.  The unagi and avocado hand roll though was great.  Also had a glass of champagne with my food which was perfect. 

I had a good time here but mostly due to the company.  The food was good but nothing memorable.  I'd come back again to try some other stuff before ruling it out as a good sushi place.
author: Denise B.

description:
Upon entering, I saw a picture of a naked fish. I took a picture and sent it to my radar (www.radar.net) and wrote, "THAT is a naked fish." A friend wrote back, "Julia, in your world, do fish wear clothes?" Point well taken.

The firecracker balls were great, the crunchy cannon rolls were great and so were the flying philadelphia rolls. Even the edamame beans were tasty. The waiter was friendly, the environment was ok and overall, I would give Naked Fish a thumbs up.
author: Julia S.

description:
The service is ok, not great; the atmosphere is nothing special, but the sushi is good. My favorite maki roles are the sunset strip and red caterpillar. The fish is fresh and you can actually taste the fish in their roles, instead of being masked by other flavors. Oh and I and I'm pretty sure the wasabi is real...as in freshly grated, which is pretty rare.

If you are looking for sushi in the marina and actually care about eating sushi, I would come here over Ace Wasabi or Mas Sake. However, if you're more concerned with drinking and having fun, I would check out one of the other two.
author: Rose K.

description:
Very cool sushi find in the Marina.  The main reason why this place gets 3 stars is for the delicious sushi rolls!  This is one of the better sushi restaurants I've been to in SF, and it's nice that it's in the Marina within walking distance of the bars on Fillmore / Chestnut.  Service and atmosphere are decent - nothing too fancy, but a great casual spot to go to on a chill day, or before heading out to the bars!

Here are suggestions for rolls I think are YUMMY:
1)  Autumn Delight
2)  Sunset Strip
3)  Tokyo Breeze

So order away, and I don't think you'll be disappointed by the tasty + beautifully made rolls! :)
author: Angela C.

description:
We went there for my housemates 23rd birthday for sake bomb's and sushi and I was actually fairly impressed.  Super atmosphere for sake bombs: didn't feel awk shouting and being loud. The waitresses were nice and attentive. The firecracker roll literally made me want to die and go to heaven, and although our bill ended up coming out to 303 dollars, that was actually cheap for the amount that we ordered. 
Plus, the asian waiter who brought us to our table was hot and had a nice ass! Two thumbs up!
author: Denys A.

description:
Had lunch here yesterday, and really enjoyed it.  The ambiance is pleasant, we sat in the back and it was a nice day so the back door was open and a soft breeze was wafting in.  The servers were friendly but we sat there just a hair too long before our order was taken...no problem, it was a Sunday and we were not in a hurry.
The food itself was delicious and fresh, starting with my simple green salad right down to all the sushi.  If you like creative rolls, this a good place for it.  The sub 1000 was fabulous.  
The price was reasonable and we left feeling satisfied and happy, although we were rushed out since it was about 3 and they were closing down between lunch and dinner.
I would go back.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Mmmm, naked fish.  Went there for the first time the other day and really enjoyed it.  It is definitely a low key establishment with a small but reasonable sized dining area.  The sake selection is good with some different choices.  I'm no expert but I would have like to seen a few more sakes in the fruity side of the spectrum as they were a little heavy in the dry sakes.

The fish was definitely fresh.  No problems there at all.  The presentation was interesting but not extravagant.  What I did like was the range of different rolls.  Too many places have a backbone of the same old stuff and add a few different rolls.  Naked fish does a good job with keeping things interesting.  I'm looking forward to heading back...soon.
author: Bryan G.

description: The Sake Sashimi literally melts in your mouth! This place is great. Sushi is super tasty and they're open late. The servers were a bit strange though. I asked to keep a menu at the table in case we wanted to order more and he laughed. He laughed like I told a funny ass joke. It weirded me out. Then when our food was coming, the waiter was walking toward us then stopped half way, hesitated, looked at the food, and then continued to head toward us. I assumed that he maybe thought he brought us the wrong order but didn't seem like it because we were the only table in the back of the restaurant. He looked really confused. I don't know. Maybe I read too much into things but I am one to notice every little thing about a place. But I digress...the sushi here is great and very tasty. We spent about $140 for 4 people. Sushi ain't cheap but it's delicious.
author: Jenny T.

description:
I've walked by Naked Fish pretty much every day for the last 5 months & figured it was a tiny little restaurant that would be impossible to get a table at. Little did I know, the restaurant extends way back!

Came on New Years day for dinner & was seating at a table for 4 right away. We were brought Edamame with our menus.

The actual sushi was very good, especially the 2000 roll (I think that's what it was called), it had white fish, avocado, jalapenos, apples, & tabico. The spicy tuna rolls were pretty good too. I would give this place 5 stars if they didn't put tabico on everything (and not mention that on the menu), I am not a huge fan.

Overall, reasonable prices, nice atmosphere & good sushi!
author: Elaine S.

description:
YEAH for awesome HAPPY HOUR- I definately left HAPPY! 
Okay- so three times a charm! As you know Naked Fish has an amazingly tantalizing happy hour- this happy hour is by far the best in the city. It is daily from 4-6p.m. and basically its 25% off all the rolls and the hot sake carafes are $3 each. 
Three of us came here for happy hour, ordered 8 rolls, edamame, 2 hot sake carafes, and two beers- total tab was $80. Fantabulous! 
Anything with unagi in it is amazing! 
Now- if you come at 4pm you will have the place to yourself, but beware; any time between 5-6pm- enter at your own risk. 
The service is not that great which sucks because the food is so good- we did have to ask for our drinks twice and they brought us someone else's food on two separate occasions while we were there. I won't speak too lowly of the waitstaff- they were busy feeding all of us Naked Fish lovers!
author: Janell D.

description: Great place for happy hour- decent sushi at fantastic prices. The service is good even when busy. I would go here for happy hour, but Wasabi and Ginger if it was for a dinner.
author: Julie M.

description: Delivery:  didn't show up after an hour.  Spoke to the restaurant and they said "the driver is on the way".  30 minutes later the food still hadn't arrived, restaurant said "driver is 15 minutes away".  canceled the order since they had lied to me 30 minutes before; will not try them again.
author: Zach F.

description:
I really enjoyed lunch at Naked Fish--the menu is pretty broad and the sushi was fresh and tasty.

Trying to get lunch on a Sunday in the Marina can be a pain, and I was relieved when I found Naked Fish to be nearly empty. It's kind of a dark, small, narrow restaurant but if you get a table in the back you can sit by the windows facing a little patio.

Service was great.

Definitely order the spicy cracker balls (giggle). I ordered miso soup, a Philly roll and some yummy skewers.
author: Sophie D.

description: Ok who serves cold unagi and warm hamachi carpaccio? Naked Fish does! YUCK. The cherry blossom roll is tasty but everthing else I ordered was just mediocre.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I liked the Naked Fish a lot! The service was superb and they were very friendly. I went during their Happy Hour (even on weekends!) and the prices were awesome.

I loved their sake nigiri (salmon) - which was incredibly fresh. The names of the rolls are hilarious. The Hot Mama and Sunset Strip were innovative and declicious. I especially loved the Sunset Strip - tuna, salmon, avocado and hibachi wrapped in a thin cucumber slice - I was in carb free heaven.

Great selection of wines and sake. 

The ambiance was nice, but the only bad thing is the seating of the restaurant.  I was practically rubbing elbows with the guy next to me and someone squeezed by our table and shoved his butt in my boyfriend's face, to get into the seat next to us. Not sexy.
author: Vanessa W.

description: First of all they have a great priced happy hour!  I love cucumber wrapped rolls and they have a great one on their happy hour menu.  Overall, their sushi is tasty and can be filling, but sometimes the service is really slow.  So go enjoy if you have a little patience.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
My date and I trekked down Chestnut peeved after we couldn't get the host at Circa to acknowledge us in an empty restaurant. We stumbled upon Naked Fish. A decent looking sushi bar that had some creative menu items.

We walk in and are PROMPTLY greeted and sat. The service was actually really great. No complaints there. My rolls were pretty decent. I remember the spicy tuna concoction being exceptionally spicy. I prefer spicy mayo over chili paste, which Nake Fish uses for their spicy rolls. Bear in mind that I was born in New Orleans and lived there for a while, so I can handle some spicy grub. So beware. It's possible that the chef was a little heavy handed.

I would definitely recommend trying to get there for happy hour. It looked like a really great deal.
author: Justin T.

description:
This place was recommended by a friend of mine who lives in the Marina - she recommended the happy hour (ends at 6:30pm) as the prices are discounted.

We were pleasantly surprised and satisfied - good service, good sushi, and reasonable prices.  The chef specials - soft crab shell and firecracker balls were my favorite.  The sushi rolls - california, spicy tuna, salmon - we standard, and good.

If you want a quick bite, good food and reasonable prices, highly recommend the happy hour.
author: Gina C.

description:
I went here Saturday night with a group of 13.  I felt like we'd been eating and drinking for days, and somehow the bill was only $32 per person.  I nearly fell out of my chair!!  There are a couple of explanations:  

1.  With the enormous amounts of sapporo we consumed, our bellies were full of liquid and we didn't need to eat very much.  

2. Much of the menu consists of generously portioned fried rolls drizzled with creamy sauces.  Not exactly your typicaly light and healthy japanese fare, and it does tend to fill you up.

Service was friendly but a bit flakey, but it's a fun place.  Good for a rowdy group on a weekend.
author: nicole l.

description: I went for happy hour once. Discounted sushi = happy Natasha. The Crunchy Cannon was fkn AMAZING. Panko fried California roll with honey mustard, unagi glaze, and tobiko. Loved the decor. I haven't been back since I stopped working in the area, but now that I'm reminded of it's lush menu, I'll return before the end of the year. That's a promise.
author: Natasha P.

description:
It was a gorgeous Saturday afternoon and the husband and I had just walked from our place in North Beach to the Sports Basement in Chrissy Field.  As we were making our way back home hunger struck.  

We were trying to decide where to eat.  Fish sounded good, but whenever I've walked by Pacific Catch, it just looks so cramped and crowded that i don't want to walk in.  

So, we're on Chestnut and we see a sign for "Naked Fish Sushi Grill Bar."  Guessing that they weren't going to grill the sushi, even without the hint that punctuation would have given, we decided to try it out.  

We hit pay-dirt!!  It was happy hour and as we munched our way through the tempura (veggie and shrimp) and marinated short rib appetizers, three rolls (Sunset Strip, Mango Tango, Hot Mama) and polished off a large Sapporo.  Everything was fantastic!!!  Don't go here if you want traditional sushi though.  This is truly new and fun stuff.  

All said and done - $36!  How do they do that?!  

I'm so going back here for another Happy Hour.  Just wish it was in a neighborhood that I frequented more often.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Awesome happy hour prices!  I don't know what time happy hour starts, but it ends at 6:30.  Beer is 1/2 off.  We had shrimp and crab fried "stars", potstickers, ahi tartare, "Show me the money" roll (spicy scallops and king crab), a california roll, 2 white tuna sashimi pieces, a vegetarian roll, tofu, 3 small bottles of Mum, 3 glasses of sauvignon blanc, 1 bottle of hot sake- and i think the bill was like $88.  Seriously.
So, prices are great here.

The food was pretty decent.  I really liked the fried stars, the Calfornia roll, and the tofu.  The sashimi was a bit oily and not great quality of fish.  Well, at $1.50 a pop, what do you expect, right?  Service was good.  

This is a great spot to hit after work with friends.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I am new to San Francisco.  I was expecting every sushi place to be amazing.  Not the case.

I ordered several different things, and only liked one roll that I tried.  The quality is not that good.  The service was very poor.  Basically, non-attentive.  

I will not go back.
author: Paul L.

description: Went here with a group of friends last Sunday night and it was dead...which meant any table in the place and really attentive service. It's relatively cheap and decent. I ordered a couple non-sushi dishes I would never order again. Stay clear of the veggie goyza (last time I checked veggies didn't resemble a tasteless ball of white mush...??) and the chicken lettuce cups weren't that great...how are you supposed to "wrap" the chicken in lettuce when you are given long and thin pieces of romaine? I probably won't go back, there are too many other good places in the area.
author: Gina C.

description:
First off, let me say I would not recommend this restaurant for dinner. However for happy hour the prices can not be beat. They have a decent selection of Sake, the fish was fresh and the rolls were CHEAP! I'm talking about 2-3 dollars for pretty damn good roll. I eat a lot, so I can blow 30+ dollars on a sushi meal, no problem. I ate 4 rolls and had a large Sapporo, whole thing totalled just a little over 20 bucks with tip...

Again happy hour was good, fresh and CHEAP.
author: Kyle K.

description: i think naked fish deserves higher ratings!!! i currently don't live in the city cause i'm away for college and anytime i'm back, literally the next day for dinner i have to come here to satisfy my sushi craving. especially for happy hour. the prices are so reasonable! i've probably been here about 10+ times. i love their black sesame ice cream. with chocolate fudge. mmmmm. and their tuna with tofu and crispy chips appetizer. my brothers always get their crunchy roll, and i think it's pretty tasty. their fish always tastes fresh and the waiters and waitresses are always pleasant!
author: Kayla O.

description:
I love the sushi here.  The fish always tastes very fresh and very flavorful.  I have not eaten a single thing off the menu that I didn't like between all of the nigiri and various rolls I have ordered or sampled from friend's plates.  The atmosphere is good too - you can go in casual clothes or dress up; either way you will feel comfortable.

Beware of one of the female waitresses - each time I ended up with her (don't know her name) she always says after you give your order 'I think you order too much food, you should get less.'  Any time someone took her advice, they left hungry.  And the first time I had this exact waitress, the service was terrible, but the next time it was fantastic?  So I'm taking off a star for this one waitress in particular who has left many of my friends hungry and one time gave me and my coworker one of the worst service experiences I've ever had from a restaurant!  I obviously care more about the food and atmosphere of a restaurant than the service due to my high rating.  So this place would get 5 stars if they got rid of that particular server.
author: Ali G.

description: Very average sushi served in an environment that tries to be trendy. Failed to impress.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The server was extremely nice but the music had too much bass that you have to yell at each other...

The presentation of the food is good. Taste wise, Aloha Sampler is pretty good but the Sunset Strip is just falling apart, literally... Firecracker Balls dish tastes like some fried food with Chinese hot sauce on it.

In conclusion, it's important to be inventive, but not to be way too different from traditional sushi.
author: T L.

description: Service was horrible.  We ordered three entrees and only one arrived.  Then our waiter disappeared.  Took forever to get remaining entrees.  I was never offered the chance to order a glass of wine.  Food was good but the service was sub standard and without personality.
author: Nick L.

description:
I think that this restaurant should be called Average Joe Sushi
Food Average not inventive average quality
Atmosphere average plain nothing special
Service average nothing special no personal attention
author: kristie l.

description:
The lunch menu is delicious, okay maybe the really bad food I had on Sunday is making this review a bit bias. 

For $9 (tax included) I was pleased with the chicken teriyaki and the california roll made with real crab, not that fish imitation crap. The takeout was perfect for an on-the-go lunch. Everything was boxed neatly and nothing spilled in the transport. 

Now that the food has settled in my happy tummy, there were slight improvements I would've made. If the salad dressing had a more substantial consistancy, I think more dressing and less salad soup. 

Overall, if you're looking for quick simple japanese food. Go naked!
author: Sara D.

description:
Randomly strolled in here tonight after seeing the sign outside about the happy hour. OMG, $3 bottle of warm sake, $3 maki rolls, $5 appetizers and 25% off house special rolls!!  We had a bottle of sake, fried oysters, spicy salmon maki, spicy tuna maki, and mango tango roll....all of this came to $21!  

The sake was decent quality..obviously their cheapest but at $3 a bottle Im so not complaining.  The fried oysters were lightly breaded and delicious.  The spicy maki rolls were AMAZING! I love me some spicy rolls and most places use what I call yuppie spice...barely enough to make me flinch.  Their rolls surprisingly (for such a nice hip looking place) were full of spice that lingered in my mouth long after.  The Mango Tango roll was amazing....so fresh and crisp...my mouth is drooling at the thought. Sure the portions weren't massively large...but with sushi it usually isnt.  Plus I glanced over the menu and even without the happy hour discounts they are pretty reasonably priced.  

Overall great service and wonderful food, with so much medicore sushi in the city, I cant wait to go back!
author: Seana L.

description:
Ehhh...went here because Ace Wasabi had an hour and a half wait.  

We had the Flying Philly, Super Dynamite, Mango Tango,  and House Tempura.  I liked the Super Dynamite the most. Just had a nice texture to it.  DYYYY NOOOOO MIIIIIIIITE!!!!!!!

I thought the portions were a little small.  The presentation was excellent.   I didn't like how the sushi chefs don't say hello to you as your walk past the kitchen like Ace Wasabi.

I guess I enjoy eating at Ace Wasabi.
author: Joel N.

description:
If Sushi Groove would just get some damn valet parking, I wouldn't have to write this review.

Picture It: San Francisco, Last Thursday night. Two young (OK, not that young anymore, but its my story) leave their Pac Heights apartment after a long day of work in search of some good sushi. We were looking to get crazy - leave our hood and our usual sushi haunts ! Having not been to Sushi Groove in years, we decided to  head over to Hyde Street for some good fish. 40 minutes of frantic parking-searching later, we gave up and went to  Naked Fish. I figured, hey, we can always get a table, and I really like the Firecracker Balls. 

15 minutes later, true to form, we were seated at Naked Fish, and our Firecracker Balls were being brought to our table. Giddy at the the thought of lightly fired spicy tuna ball surrounded by a trio of yummy sauces, the smiles were immediately wiped off our of faces when the plate set in front of us appeared to have - brace yourself - gasp - burnt sushi on it. Yes, you read that right - BURNT sushi. Is it possible? Is it an oxymoron of epic proportions?

Undeterred, we though maybe it had been a while since we had the balls of fire and maybe we had forgetten that they appear charred so we dug in. Nope, those things were burnt. We doused them in sauce and slathered on the wasabi, but nothing could get rid of the deep fried burnt taste. Very disappointing.

We had ordered a couple other rolls and they soon showed up so we went ahead and ate. The Super Dynamite Roll is pretty good and is the reason Naked Fish gets  one star from me. The other star is for the quick service. The Very Hot Mama is just plain awful - warm bland crab covered with baked salmon and served in tin foil. It was like something out of Betty Crocker's Cookbook, circa 1950. Ouch, I can't believe I just dissed Betty like that, but even she wouldn't try to pass this off as "sushi".

To add insult to injury, our bill showed up listing 7 rolls on it (we had ordered and received 4) but we were so eager to leave that we just paid it and left.
author: Megan L.

description:
I'm finding that Chestnut restaurants are mediocre.  I can't figure out why, since the patron base and money is there.  

We tried this place and although I'm not floored by the sushi, I'm loving the happy hour prices.  The amount of sushi and beer we enjoyed for $20 was impressive. The sushi is fresh but not the melt in your mouth good, but I still go back. The service and location to home are a big plus too. Three nights a week and who needs to go grocery shopping plus you eat early enough to have time for a stroll after dinner.
author: Tamz O.

description: Came to visit friends and they suggested this place and I am glad they did. We went Sunday night and had great service. It was probably due to the lack of clientele present, but that was our good luck. Rolls are all good. We had the red caterpillar and wanted more. Sashimi special was fresh and fantastic. So good we ordered another Walu. Plenty if food and sake for four and only spent $150. Well worth it. Only bad item was deep fried softshell crab. Oil tasted like it needed to be changed out, had a burnt taste. Highly recommend.
author: Rich H.

description:
Finally revisited the Marina because the recent iPhone ads made me crave the poke at Pacific Catch. But not enough to wait 35 minutes at 8:30 on a Tuesday.  We then walked down to Ace Wasabi where the delay was, unsurprisingly, even worse.  

As I stood there, blood sugar dropping dangerously low, throwing withering dagger glances at my fiancee, we spotted a HUGE sign for Naked Fish. Like a hungry fish to a big shiny lure, we both bit hard.     

All I can say is that the taste of fishy salmon is still lurking and my stomach is still turning from the pork lettuce wraps, which are an even worse invention than my pre-cooked chicken and ranch on english muffin sandwiches.

The service was nice and the sushi bar was the most full I've ever seen.  Overall though, it has sworn me off of sushi for a month or two.
author: Gina W.

description:
The happy hour is great, but the sushi isn't. It seemed somewhat dry to me and my table had to beg for more pickled ginger. 

Meh. I've experienced better.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Love it here and love their delivery service. So convenient. Firecracker balls and tuna tartar are to die for.
author: Tony L.

description: Quality sushi here - good neighborhood spot.  Good service too.  They forgot my Wasabi and Ginger but rushed back quickly and the delivery man refused the second tip even though this clearly wasn't his fault.
author: Jackson G.

description:
This is definitely NOT where you want to go for sushi. 

The sushi wasn't great. For some reason it was freezing (people were wearing puffy north-face jackets). The only thing that saved the dinner was the good company we had.

I wouldn't say Naked FIsh is bad. The service is decent and the $3 Sapporos are cool, but this is SF. You should leave the sushi restaurant with a huge smile on your face. 

Check out some other spots.
author: Mike D.

description:
Although it took 20 mins. to find parking in this neighborhood, I will have to say that the food made up for it.  Every item which we ordered was served with minimal wait time and the sushi was fresh and yummy. The wait-staff was also courteous and attentive.

For starters, we ordered the Spicy Fried Calamari.  Fried perfectly with a hint of jalapeño, I would definitely recommend this dish to anyone that loves calamari.  Although the tartar sauce that accompanied this appetizer was a bit more spicy than expected, I was still content without the sauce when eating it.  Next we had Albacore Tataki.  The flavors of the ponzu sauce, sweet onions & thin slices of tuna meshed so well, it was effortless to eat . The Naked Fish roll came after.  An unagi & avocado rolled topped with yellowtail & tuna and wrapped in soy paper.  The texture of this roll was different than the rolls I ordinarily eat, due to the soy paper.  But all the ingredients combined, worked well together.  

One of my favorite dishes of the night was the Ankimo (Monkfish foie tossed with salmon roe & tobiko).  These little bit size cylindrical patties of foie melted in my mouth and bursted with great flavor.  Lastly, we had the Tasmanian Salmon Tower.  This dish was perfect in every way.  Baked in honey sauce,  2 slices of salmon patty separated by grilled asparagus.  The salmon was not undercooked nor overcooked.  This dish came out wonderful in both presentation and taste.  The sweetness of the honey sauce and the freshness of the salmon made this dish a delight to eat. 

I would highly recommend Naked Fish to anyone that enjoys discovering new creations in Japanese food.
author: Vindy C.

description:
More like 3.5 stars! We've been here twice, once for regular dinner and once for happy hour and gotta say that it's pretty good standard sushi, and happy hour prices are really good - regular rolls and hand rolls and some entrees are cheap eats and worth it at happy hour! rice is good and fish quality is good. Some of their specialties are kinda odd and not as tasty as they sound (like a quail egg on salmon and sushi) but still ok.

Try their sake mojito! mmmmmm I'd like one now, it's so hot in SF!!!

I'd actually come back again :-)
author: Paolo D.

description:
OK,

So it's not real sushi.  I'm no purist.  The stuff I found really tasty was all cooked...loved those firecracker balls (or something like that).

The key is to go on a weeknight.  On Fridays and Saturdays they're crowded and the quality and service drops off notably.  Plus they're playing the damn turntable lounge music crap way too loud for you to even have a conversation.  Weekends they get 2 stars, weeknights they get 4...well maybe 3.5 but I'll stick with my 3* rating.

Oh and for a trendy Marina place they really do have an absolutely pathetic winelist.
author: Jay W.

description:
This place was recommended to me by a friend who comes here religiously for their happy hour.  My first visit was for a weeknight happy hour, and my friend was right, it was pretty good!  Drinks, sushi and appetizers were all majorly discounted, and while it's not their complete menu there is certainly enough to keep things interesting.  The sake mojito is enormous!

A few weeks later I came here for a regular dinner (not at happy hour), and we were excited that there wasn't a wait on a Saturday night.  The menu was much more extensive than the happy hour one, and prices were still reasonable.  I had the most amazing roll ever, which of course I can't remember the name of, but this is what it was: no rice, no seaweed, super thinly sliced cucumber wrapped around tuna, hamachi, salmon and avocado.  Four pieces per order, and oh my god it was fantastic!  Next time I am certainly ordering it again!

If you're coming here on a date or just want some extra privacy while you dine, they have one table that is a little booth behind some heavy velvet curtains.  You can probably call and reserve it, though I'm not positive about that.  A bit odd for a sushi place, but kinda cool nonetheless.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
4 stars for good happy hour menu. 3 stars for friendly but often times slow service. So their happy hour is from 4-6:30pm, with service being so slow it's good to get there before or by 6pm to make sure you get your orders in. Their beers and hot sake are 50% off. Nigiri $1.50/pc, variety of hot appetizers $4.95, 25% off special rolls. $3 for big Kirin or Sapporo is awesome, comes very chilled!

My husband and I discovered this place right near our house recently and have gone 1x week to get our sushi fix. This place is 4 stars compared to similar sushi places of its class (just below Zushi)....Zushi Puzzle has better fish for sure and costs more. Naked Fish is more middle of the range but the Nigiri is pretty fresh and it is a closer alternative with more variety than Nippon. Actually, we haven't been to Nippon in a very long time b/c it's not worth driving over there for take out anymore.

At Naked Fish we typically spend around $40-60 including tax tip. We have about 5-7 pieces of nigiri each (saba, aji, tai, hamachi, kanpachi, scallop and halibut are good,  the walu hawaiian butterfish is hit and miss b/c seems to taste very watered down.) My favorite hot appetizer is the agedashi tofu. The short ribs are yummy but very fatty.  I've tried about 5 different appetizers but I'd rather pass them up and get maki rolls ($3/ea) or a hand roll ($2/ea) instead. My fave maki rolls are the spicy tuna , negi hamachi, vegi futomaki. Spicy scallop handroll is good.  On to the special rolls, I'd recommend: Sub 1000, Crunchy cannon, mango tango but don't go overboard on the mango sauce.

Go enjoy yourself and try to ignore the sometimes strange choice of music..it's always different when we come and once time it was blasted so loud it was hard to carry on a conversation but they figured it out fairly quickly and turned it down.
author: Mellie D.

description:
July 2007 update:  Apparently thye are under new ownership since January.  My 5 star review no longer stands.  Quality is WAY down.  We ordered Salmon Nigiri (simple, right?) and it still had the silver skin on the side...not a little piece, but a whole side. Yuck. Service also down. 
--------------------

Good quality sushi, creative rolls, hard to find fish, great sake mojito, cool ambiance.  However, have to agree with the sternkid about the service and the "missing" items.  I asked for one item and the gal rattled off like 10 things that they were out of.  Anyway, if I can stand the pricetag, I'll definitely be back to try some other new things!

Edit - changing to 5 stars....continue to be impressed. Red dragon roll is very good.  Service was spectacular by both the host and server.
author: Angela T.

description:
Their happy hour sushi and sake specials are great. Normally I don't really go for those warm, creamy, westernized baked, gooey rolls but they make one with salmon that is freaking melt-on-your-chopsticks incredible. I don't remember the name of it though so you will just have to experiment. 

great atmosphere, great service. 

only problem: it's in the freakin marina.
author: Geryon R.

description:
Wow, what a cool lounge.

The sushi is very interesting and god. Can't remember exactly what we ordered, but try the more exotic items, they are rewarding. 

They don't have too many beers, which for me is dissapointing, and their sake could be hotter.

I think what makes me give this place 4 stars is that a.) As shallow as it is, all the servers are beyond cute, b.) there is plenty of space and you can fit a party of friends, c.) the sushi is good. 

So there you are. Wish I could give it 3.5
author: Jay C.

description: Pretty good place with a nice feel. The sushi and rolls were fairly good - some of the rolls were definitely creative concoctions, but they were good and edible. The seaweed salad was a bit too flavorful (too much vinegar and sugar?).
author: Chihee K.

description: This place is tasty and gives out free edamame as an appetizer, whereas most places charge around $2.50 . I'd agree with some of the other posts saying that the service isn't great. It's often hard to find the waiter or waitress after the food is brought to the table and it is never explained what the rolls/fish are.  Regardless, the fish is good and its a fun atmosphere for a dinner with the girls.
author: Emily K.

description:
I went to Naked Fish for a bento box lunch, and I will definitely go again. Their tonkatsu was light, and perfectly breaded. The miso soup bowl was really ample. The only thing is that I didn't like being made to sit either at the bar or at a bar table for lunch - it's not the most comfortable.

For lunch there is no loud thumping trendy music that blasts in your face at 135bpm to remind you that you're in the Marina trying to re-capture your youth; there are trendy lights underneath the bar that are washed out by natural light during lunchtime. The tea is yummy, walking distance from work, reasonably priced and yummy bento boxes.

I was pleasantly surprised, thank you Naked Fish!
author: dj z.

description: Good food, SHITTY service. Like REAL SHITTY, but the food was delicious. Oh and parking sucks and the restrooms are not th best. But the food is tasty.
author: Bobby B.

description:
After trying this place out once and experiencing terrible service, I decided to give this restaurant the benefit of the doubt and offer a second chance.  The first time I ate here with five of my friends, my food arrived 45 minutes after my friend's meals.  The second time I dined at this place, the exact same thing happened.  As an apology, the waiter said my meal would be on the house.  Later, when he brought the bill around, he explained that he had to charge me for the food anyway, and couldn't negotiate.

This was more than a little irritating.  I have also heard that if you are blond and have blue eyes, you will be served before all others at this restaurant.  They seem to take orders and serve food by skin color gradient, descending from light to dark.  If you don't believe this, try this place out with a group of your multicultural friends and see for yourself.  I don't want to judge, but it is kind of unbelievable how closely they stuck to that rumor when I dined there.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I ordered delivery from Naked Fish and terrible quality sushi arrived 1:20 minutes after I ordered.  The estimate was an hour which is fine had the food been freshly prepared.  I called and was told it had been out for delivery for an hour so should be here any minute...who in the world thinks that sushi that has been in a car for an hour is acceptable?  They didn't offer to discount anything, they didn't even apologize!  Rather, they sent the delivery guy back 20 minutes later to pick up the food!  

Of all places I want to see top notch quality controls, a sushi restaurant tops that list.  I'll never eat at Naked Fish again because I don't trust their interpretation of "acceptable"...let alone quality!
author: Josh M.

description:
I've been here many times and its really the only place in the Marina that I go to.  It's not pretentious like many of the other Marina spots I've been too.  Not knocking the marina.. it is what it is.. and its not for me for the most part.

The food is incredible here in my opinion, love the Firecracker Balls especially.  The pricing is very fair, and if your a regular, you can expect free sake just about every visit, especially if you're friendly with the staff, which I am, and for good reason.. they're extremely interesting and friendly.

I wish I was more of a food expert so I could use large words and claim that my palet for sushi is better than yours and then claim nay say on your reviews.. however I'm no word smith and i'm definitely no sushi conisouer.. and I"m not even sure if I spelt that correctly..

But if your average white joe who's somehow landed in the marina and your looking for a fair priced, fun, somewhat trendy sushi spot to hang out at that isn't packed beyond its capacity and has friendly staff.. this is it.

Oh and my food and drinks always arive promptly which is a plus!
author: Oliver S.

description:
Average Joe.

I'd go here for rolls, but definitely skip out on the sashimi.  They do put a heavy emphasis on Sriracha which I find annoying some times.  That stuff really kills the taste of anything you're eating.  A drop is good enough for an entire roll.  Anyway, I'd go again for a quick fix, but probably will try to check out other places before that happens.
author: James F.

description:
I am happy to say after months and months of talking about eating here one of my good friends and I finally did...and we were not disappointed!! We weren't sure if we were going to eat here at first. We were standing outside looking at the menu when one of the customers coming out says "If you don't go inside there and eat you're STUPID!" We looked at each other and were like we really have to try this place out now. 

It has a semi-similar look to Ace Wasabi a few restaurants up. It's very modern but not as good music as Ace Wasabi. The wait staff is very friendly and are quick to give recommendations if it is your first time there.  The only complaint was that it took FOREVER to get our drinks...but the sodas are like two cans of sodas in one HUGE glass. So that kinda makes up for it.

The food was DELICIOUS!! We ordered the Kiwi Steak which was awesome. A bit spicy but that's okay with me. You can ask for them to not use so much of the green sauce that it's covered with. A great dish for sharing. We also ordered some rolls the "Show me the Money" roll which has spicy scallop and snow crab inside topped off with a seaweed salad....MY FAVORITE of the MEAL. The other roll we got was the "Marina Angel" which is salmon with asparagus inside...YUMMO! We also ordered some nigiri...they had TORO! I'm telling you if you haven't had any it's like BUTTA BABY!! The regular tuna nigiri was so so...i think it could have been cut a bit better. 

Overall it was a good experience...I will definitely be back again! Ace Wasabi has some competition for my heart now
author: Jazmine S.

description:
I've lived about 2 blocks away from Naked FIsh for a few years now and it's still my go-to never fail always fresh and tasty and satisfies my sushi cravings despite all the other sushi joints around the chestnut / fillmore scene.  

We've enjoyed the happy hour (although I've only once made it home in time from work to get in before the 6:30 cut off) but most often we go for a tasting round.  We ALWAYS get the firecracker balls and spicy tuna roll and i've just started to get back into enjoying the wonderful simplicity of nigiri.  

Now, i've had nigiri before and fancy rolls are good almost everywhere (save all you can eat sushi joints).  But the nigiri at Naket Fish are HUGE.  I mean thick juicy, sweet, savory, and buttery salmon nigiri, eel nigiri, tender ebi...it really doesn't get any better than when the simplest slices of fish are just pure and good.  

Also, love me some sake mojitos!!  (they're HUGE).
author: Crystal K.

description:
I've ignored this neighborhood place for too long, but recent visits and take-out has turned me on to it. 

Their sashimi/nigiri has been consistently good. The Autumn Delight is a killer roll, simple and tasty. Service is great, friendly and quick, both eating in and for take out. Now in my local dining rotation...
author: Jason M.

description:
We were pleasantly surprised by this place. We were trying for a last minute table at Zushi Puzzle, but it was an hour plus wait so we headed down Chestnut to see what we could find. Knowing we were in the Marina, and knowing that you sometimes get more of a scene than actual good food, our hopes were not too high. But this place rocked. The fish was really delicious, fresh and generous, and they had a really unique menu of specialty rolls so we picked a couple of those as well.

We'll be back...
author: Chris L.

description:
Naked Fish is one of my favorite sushi spots in the city. 

The fish is always fresh and the ambiance is great! The menu is creative and dishes are brought out once they are ready to ensure freshness. 

I haven't been yet but I've heard that they have a great happy hour (1/2 priced sake and hand rolls!)
author: Summer C.

description: Sushi and I are one and even more so at Naked Fish. The firecracker balls are a bundle of absolute goodness in your mouth. The staff is friendly, the fish is fresh and there is a nice vibe. It's a little dark and too crowded at times to move and feel comfortable, but overall, two thumbs up!
author: Julia S.

description: Solid place.  I judge by tuna / yellow tail / salmon nigiri.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I my search for a nice sushi place in the Marina, I bumped into the Naked Fish, and the conclusion is the same as the rating 'mwa... it's okay'.

I think the best way to describe the place is a progressive sushi place, since most traditional dishes are dressed up or modified a little. It's not necessarily a bad thing, although I like sushi rolls better when they are just basic, and not covered with fancy sauces. Apart from that I do have to say the salad was pretty good.

The layout however: there are some single and double seat places in front, and some tables in the back. These two parts of the restaurant are divided by the kitchen, which means the feel and atmosphere is not too great. Also the service was a little slow when I was there. This doesn't make Naked Fish a bad place, but I can't say I'll be back very often.
author: Frank d.

description: Great food, great sake selection, reasonable prices.  Staff are friendly but some aren't as "on the ball" as others, forgetting orders, taking dishes too early, etc... Not a biggie, though, we were there several hours and mostly got excellent service.
author: Christopher M.

description:
This was my go to place for sushi when I worked in the Marina. There's three choices all within a block of the Apple store on Chestnut - Naked Fish, Enoshima, and Ace Wasabi. 

Enoshima is more authentic and less expensive but definitely not as good as Naked fish - you get what you pay for. Ace Wasabi is usually pretty expensive and not necessarily anything spectacular. The service has always been friendly and helpful and if you go during happy hour you can fill up and get wasted for pretty cheap.

Some of my fav's.... Hot Mama Special, Fire Cracker Balls and the Sub 1000. Order them all, you'll thank me.
author: James N.

description:
Updated 12/29/07

If there is a sushi hell this place is surely in the running. The new owners have ruined this place -- nothing is the same, the ambiance is far too bright now and they've even changed the Hot Mamma role. Why mess with perfection? I gave it a second chance this weekend, but still the fish was fishy and the service pretty lackluster. I barely finished one glass of wine, and my friends, that is saying something.

Perhaps it's just the fact my sushi standards have improved dramatically over the past four years I've lived here, but Naked Fish just doesn't do it for me anymore. Sometimes a girl has to face the facts and in this case, the sushi just isn't as fresh as other places. Even my beloved Hot Mamma roll didn't seem too spectacular. One thing to note, NF HAS recently come under new ownership, so I noticed some "improvements" like edamame is now complimentary! And at least they serve it before the meal, as God intended. (If you've read my Blowfish review you'll understand what I mean.)
author: a p.

description:
I LOVE this place. Granted, the first time I went we started with an unhealthy amount of sake bombs and everything tasted absolutely amazing. But since then, I have gone slightly less intoxicated and have loved everything there. 

The fire cracker balls--wow. Name in and of itself speaks for them. I love their spicy tuna roll, mainly because it isn't drowned in mayonnaise like some of them can be. And because I love siracha sauce. Love love love their dragon roll and the Hot Mama. Great variety of rolls, sashimi isn't bad (though not my favorite), and the service and atmosphere are good too. Not to mention a pretty sweet happy hour!
author: Kristin B.

description:
Good food, interesting recipes for sushi. For example: jalapenos, avocado, cream cheese and fish! 

The place is small and minimalistic which is nice. It is not too fancy but it remains classy and on the quieter end. Could be a good casual date place.

The service however, is too slow. So if you don't mind sitting and waiting - it's a good place. I wouldn't recommend if you are in a rush.
author: Madhu P.

description:
Food/quality:
The sushi here was just average, but the sake was great!

Service:
Service was friendly and attentive. 

Atmosphere: 
The inside is somewhat trendy, trying to fit into the Marina scene.

Value:
Not a great value as the sushi was mediocre.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Can't go wrong here...the food is good, the prices cheap, and some interesting rolls.  Plus free edamame - bonus.

If you wan a nice, cheap, consistently good sushi place - go here.  Its nothing to write home about, but its definitely worth your money.
author: Rebecca W B.

description:
I brought a friend here for lunch who was in from the mid-west and has heard how good the sushi is here.
We had THE worst service ever.  They forgot a put our order in and we were there for over an hour. They never aplogized,  we had to keep asking for basics like water while they were all over this table of guys drinking Sake and beer.  We thought they must have been dating the waitstaff. By the time we got our food, we had to "wolf" it down because we were late for the airport. Sushi was very mediocre. Overall terrible dining experience!
author: Scott R.

description: I was really surprised to see the mixed reviews!  It is not traditional sushi, but that is what makes it special.  I went yesterday for the first time, and we were really happy with it because the flavors were unexpected.  We had a roll with salmon, crab meat with a thin lemon wedge on top, and the lemon was a really nice subtle touch.  The 49rs roll was really good too, but the highlight was the Sunrise; a 2-piece roll of tuna, salmon roe and a quail egg on top that was just amazing.  We were really tempted to order a 2nd portion.  I don't live in the neighborhood, but we will definitely be back I am in the Marina.
author: Vivian P.

description: I really like coming here for their HH special.  They have 1/2 off sake and beer, a special HH menu w/ apps and rolls and a discount on the regular rolls (I think it's 25% off).  The service is good and they always come around right before HH is ending and do a last call and let you order up a ton of stuff so you get the HH price and you can just hang out for a while after.  I liked the baked roll and the cucumber wrapped roll and the firecracker balls.  YUM.  Yay for another Sushi HH option in the neighborhood :-)
author: Selena G.

description: I should start by saying this is not the best sushi in the world.  It is fresh and good but not the best.  I mostly go for happy hour. $3 rolls and $3 large beers is a great way to end the work day.  The interior is a little run down, clean, but not so pretty. Maybe the money they save on not renovating, they pass on to the customer during happy hour.  Cold cheap beer with cold fresh fish is all I really need.
author: Justin N.

description: Great Sushi, especially during happy hour times before 6:30pm. Highly recommend to try the hand rolls.
author: sasha z.

description:
Naked Fish is a great neighborhood joint to hit up if you just want to enjoy some reliably good sushi in a low key, friendly atmosphere.  I'd give this place 5 stars if it were just based on service alone.  Everyone at Naked Fish is SUPER nice.  I went down to 4 stars because the sushi is good... not great.

Oh, and their happy hour is stellar if you can get there before 6 (I think it ends at 6).
author: Megan M.

description:
We ended up here because it was easy to get a table for 7 without a wait or reservation. 
The fish here was surprisingly fresh but the presentation was awkward. The rolls depart from traditional sushi in an unsuccessful attempt at creativity. We ended up with several rolls that were wrapped in cucumber and used mayo for binding when we were expecting more traditional sushi rolls (so read the menu carefully). The firecracker balls were the best thing we tried. The waitstaff was efficient but not very helpful or friendly.
The environment is comfortable and reasonably upscale.  
They serve beer, wine and sake. 
I would say if you are in the neighborhood, and want to grab a quick bite, this place is sufficient. Don't go out of your way to seek it out.
author: sarah a.

description:
Best California Rolls I have had in San Francisco!  Their day time lunch box is a steal. You get miso soup, rice, salad, rolls, and another dish of your choice for $8.

I eat here once a week!
author: Kelley B.

description: My husband and I came across this venue by accident while taking a walk in the area.  At first, the restaurant seemed quite small and dark, but after you walk through a narrow hallway, we reached a dimly lit seating area with a casual but nice ambience.  The sushi was phenomenal, and the service was great (including unlimited edamame).  The best roll we had was the super dynamite roll, dragon roll, spicy tuna roll, and the salmon sashimi. We would definitely come back to this restaurant again.
author: Tommy Bruin F.

description:
Food is good.  Recommend to try walu in sashimi.  Waitress are nice.

I would have given it a 4, but it's a bit pricey to deduct one star.  We ordered two entries (one sashimi and two sushi).  Normally that's only about one person's quantity for us, and the bill already came out to be $40+. (though to be fair, it's in a high rent area, so at some degrees this might be understandable.)
author: Alex D.

description: You have to check this place out for happy hour, great deals on sushi and booze.
author: Matt B.

description: by far the best!! sushi happy hour...i come here when ever im near by, but if i am going to be in the area i plan it rite so i can be there for happy hour jajaja...
author: Ivan C.

description: We came on a Saturday night for four people and were able to get seated with no wait time.  We ordered a bunch of sushi and it came out fairly fast and they all tasted fresh.  Nothing really stood out to me.  Overall, not the best sushi that I've had, but it was good and decently priced.
author: Kat X.

description: I was very impressed with the quality of the food here.  I went with my roommates for happy hour and it was excellent.  The portions for the price were very good.  I will admit this is one of the best sushi places I've been to in a long time.  Parking can be an issue sometimes, but it's not that bad and worth it.
author: Brian C.

description: I love sushi.  However I decided to try to some new items ..I did get one roll though- the hot moma roll and the oysters which were ok- I would pass on those next time (if there is another next time- I certainly wont seek it out), the lamb chops were very tasty though not always enough- It came with 2 ...would get that again and the Green tea ice cream- a must have!!
author: Margo R.

description:
It was quite good, but not great. Certainly one of the better places we've had sushi at. Decided to go there because city search gave it #8 out of the top 10 sushi places in SF. So from that standpoint we were a little disappointed. 

Pros:
1. They have a nice sake / drink menu. 
2. Fish was all fresh, well prepared, well cut, etc.
3. Menu is quite experimental. 
4. Price wasn't bad either. 

Cons:
1. The menu is quite experimental. This can be a bad thing especially since their menu lacks many of the old standbys. All I can say about this is that the Mango Tango was surprisingly bland and the crab meat may have been a little off (maybe do something with blood orange instead of mango) and there were far too many cooked/seared items. 

I hope that they change their menu up frequently as I don't think I'd be able to go there more than twice and order strictly sushi without getting bored. 

That aside it was all excellent. The Mango tango was a disappointment but the Sunset Strip, tuna, red caterpillar were all quite good. I would definitely say give this place a try if you want to try some more experimental sushi rolls.
author: Jonathan Z.

description:
Deceptively larger.

I've always walked by and only saw the bar, but when my friends invited me to go out to eat here I was surprised that I didn't see them at the bar.  I made my way back and found many tables... and with people at them.  One of them had my friends patiently waiting for me.

The rolls were good especially the Marina... I forgot the full name.
The Fire Cracker meatballs were good too.
The rest was average and I don't remember them too well
I love Toro and they had 4pcs of sashimi for $20.00  Pretty big pcs and decent.
Beer and Sake were ordered and brought a smile to all.

The place is clean and the service is good
author: Po L.

description: In the space of a few months since my last visit, quality has dramatically deteriorated. I can no longer recommend Naked Fish.
author: Live F.

description: Foods good..great service.. Good rolls... Free edamame.... Saki mojitios...yum..... Miso soup needs work
author: Shauna P.

description: Ahi avocado salad was a great! I would go back just for that.
author: Laura P.

description: This place has a great sushi menu. I usually don't like rolls that are cooked, but their Hot Mama Special is to die for. They have some run-of-the-mill stuff, but they also offer some really cool, unique rolls, like the Sub 1000. It is very different and I've had it three times but still can't tell if I like it. There is usually a long wait for a table if it's a weekend day. For a while there, the hostess recognized me whenever I came in. Now, they have someone different  greeting me every time I go there. The food is still good though, so I guess it doesn't really matter if they know me or not.
author: Halee T.

description: YUM. Wow the sushi is so fresh and so delicious here. Had a sample of several rolls including the dragon, autumn, rainbow, salmon nigiri, and sashimi. Also tried the new york steak. Everything was really good, and reasonably price. I just wish they were bigger portions because at this rate, I feel sorry for whoever is eating with me and paying the bill. ;)
author: Hue M.

description:
What's all the fuss about?  I ate here after reading review on citysearch and yelp.

The food was really good, but not spectacular.
author: Jen N.

description: The fish here is very fresh and the rolls and sashimi were very tasty.  Unfortunately, though, the one bad thing about this place was exactly what Yelpers have raved about: the firecracker balls, which were essentially deep fried rice balls with a teeny tiny bit of something slightly resembling fish inside and totally drenched in orangey and black sauces.  BLEH... if you like real sushi, DO NOT order this -- you will be disappointed!!! Other than that, this place had some darn good fresh fish!
author: Grace M.

description: they have pretty good quality sushi and their customer service is very friendly. their place is not huge but very cozy. Their delivery service is really good too. I would definitely recommend.
author: emily a.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to this little spot last night for some sushi and came out pretty full :)

Our reservations were for 8:30 and I can see where people got the impression of the "scene." When we arrived, there were some loud obnoxious types hogging the airwaves, but after they left around 9-9:30, it was great. 

Our server was great and was pleased to tell us about the Walu fish and had some great recommendations on the menu. The Sake Mojito was fantastic!
author: SandJ C.

description:
Ah ha...a hidden gem, all the dishes are tasy: SuperDynamite and FireCracker Balls are superb, and the edamame is warm. Prices are reasonable, service is great and its easy to get in and out of there with friends as a nice pre-party place. TRY IT

Oh yes.. 5 Stars
author: M P.

description:
4 stars for the sushi, 5+ stars for the kick ass happy hour prices. I went with a friend and we had a whole bunch of rolls and happy hour specials (no drinks though) and the bill was only 18 bucks! 

what's even better is the sushi was still very, very fresh and comparable to any other sushi establishment in the marina. not quite sushi ran, but for 1/4 the price, who cares!
author: Matt K.

description:
OK i have to be honest, it only lost stars for the price.  Why 2 stars?  Because it's THAT pricey.  holy crap.  No food is worth a frickin' mortgage payment.  

And now... to the food.

Yummy.  Clean.  Fresh, melts in your mouth, blah blah blah.  Excellent service.  Very attentive.  Very impressive.  But kinda sorta too stuffy for me.  Whatever.
author: Edith h.

description: 5 stars for the nigiri sushi that was extremely fresh and delicious. I had sake (salmon) hamachi, amberjack and Walu. Also for the fact that I went at lunch and one thing I wanted to try was not on the lunch menu, only on the dinner one,  and the sushi chef still made it for me. It was a miso walu tini. Walu, a butterfish, cut in small chunks,, marinated in miso, a wee bit of salad and thinly sliced cucumber served in a martini glass. Absolutely delicious. The place is clean, modern and hip. The service excellent. The menu has limited rolls that I would order, but I usually order just nigiri and couldn't have been happier. I would drive over the GG bridge anytime to eat here. The prices are fantastic. Each nigiri was only $3.80 each. A real bargain for extremely fresh fish and great atmosphere.
author: Christine E.

description:
Before I say something,
This place is a lot better than "Okazu-Ya" type of Sushi places.
A lot better.
Even 2 stars.
Okazu-Ya type Sushi is Minus 10, with Dark Stars!
But Yelp doesn't even have Zero stars.
Hey, Yelp! we should have Zero star option. 
well,
I decided not to blame Yuppie Americans for Pseudo Sushi.
Not anymore!
Because, 
this place is for typical Yuppie Americans who has a small mouth.
I don't have any problem to see the young blonde women sitting at the counter eating sushi using chopsticks.
A young, blonde woman with chopsticks!?
Most Asian men from Asia love that.
They like a small mouth.
And they might say, "Me So Horny".
Right?
But, 
Not Me.
I am not that kind of man, period.
So,
I behaved at this place last night because I was on a date with my girlfriend.
I don't need to look around anymore.
So,
Back on the subject about Naked Sushi,
Chinese Sushi Chef,
Latinos at the Grill,
White waiters and waitresses. They were very good & polite.
Pretty clean.
I think they are working together very well.
But,
This place gave me such small Nigiris!
Even though it has dimples and good slice.
This place is Not my kind.
Nigiri was way too small.
$60 - for 2 people.
Not enough food,
even yakitori was only 2 little skewers for $7!
It was too small.
Everything was tiny.
I wasn't satisfied by their food because the portion they gave us.
Another Premature Ejaculation kinda sushi.
author: Nobu K.

description: Great happy hour sushi deals and delicious sushi. The perfect place to stop for a quick bite!
author: Kelsey G.

description:
I'll have an order of toro sashimi. 
Sorry we're out tonight. 
What about your __________ roll?
Sorry, we're out of that too.
Okay, i'll have some albacore sashimi. 
Uh, we dont do albacore sashimi. We do albacore nigiri, though. 
So, what youre telling me is you can take a piece of albacore and lay it across a pat of rice, but you cant just take that same piece of albacore and not put it on top of anything and simply place it on my plate?
Well, I guess we could, I just dont know how to enter it into the computer.

That was part of my conversation with our waitress. It didnt get any better as the night progressed.

Someone at our table ordered a mixed sake drink. She replied, "Our bartender who knows how to mix drinks isnt in tonight."

Saying this is the 'best sushi in the marina' is like saying 'alec is the best baldwin.' youre not really comparing it to anything. 

There was hardly anything done right. The heat was on full blast melting both people and their sushi. Our waitress wasnt very knowledgeable of the menu. She was forgetful on several occassions on things we asked for.  Granted she had too many tables, but not my problem. The ambience is a failure at being trendy. Rather a drab, minimalist attempt.

The sushi was average; pedestrian at best. Add the price per portion and this brotha says, 'Naked fish ain't worth its weight in wasabi.'
author: the sternkid ..

description:
the name of this place has such an allure that i have been wanting to try it out for a while now.

the first impression was good.  they have some seats at the bar and a couple of tall tables with bar stools for a more casual seating.

in the back, there are plenty of tables and can accomodate large groups.  unfortunately, the night i went, there was a rather large and rowdy group of guys.  it was deafening.

the food itself is average.  i sampled the rainbow and the naked fish rolls.  good but not memorable.  the sake sashimi was good but i expected more of the butterfish nigiri.  ace wasabi does a better cut of this fish.

the service though was very fast...almost too fast.  all the food came out at the same time and there wasn't much room to accomodate it well.  but the servers were really friendly nonetheless.  

there are so many other sushi places to eat at in that area so i probably won't be back.
author: Anh V.

description: Very good sushi "roll" place. Lots of specialty rolls and everything is really tasty. We had some appetizers too which were all pretty decent. The happy hour is the most incredible deal ever. It's one of our (a group of 3 of us) favorite happy hour in the City.
author: Cake W.

description: I've eaten in and ordered from Naked Fish over the last 4 years more than 20 times. They were my favorite sushi place because they had fresh food and price was appropriate for the portions. (super dynamite roll, firecracker balls & seared ahi are my favs) However, the last few months (I ordered delivery 4 times) the portions are becoming less and less. The beef teriyaki dinner used to have more meat and included a side of sauce. The last order literally had 5 pieces of lettuce as their salad. I hope they increase their standards when sending food out in the future because I really do like this place and want to keep coming back!
author: Jen S.

description: I love Japanese food, and always lookin for sushi, but with different twist.  Naked Fish is one of those places. Even better is when you can get that food at a bargin price.  Well, they have happy hour everyday, 4-6:30 pm M-Th and 4-6 Fri-Sun.  If you can't make it, it's still worth a visit. The best appetizers are the bbq short ribs and deep fried calimari, but ask if you can have the lemon ponzu sauce for the calimari. To me it goes much better than the spicy mayo. They have a variety of special rolls, i like the crunchy cannon, hot mama special, red catapiller, and autumn delight. You also have to try the kiwi steak, great flavors. Available during happy hour only, I like the vegetable futomaki.  Simple minimalist decour, standard service, really try to make the happy hour, that's a deal!
author: Michael D.

description: Small sushi place in the Marina that is actually quite good. Everything from the service to the detail they place on their dishes really impressed me. Try the assorted fish rapped with cucumber...really refreshing. Really entertaining bar tender too.
author: Jen J.

description: Okay, the atmosphere is a little cheesy, but Naked Fish is pretty good stuff. If you want the best experience, stay away from the sushi rolls, and stick to sashimi and appetizers. The Miso Walu-Tini is fantastic...
author: Brianne K.

description: I LOVE Naked Fish! I'm giving it 4 stars because i think the place could stand to be a little bigger, but besides that this place is GREAT! The happy hour (4:30 to 6:30) there is to die for! Everything has that awesome fresh taste and the hotate is SO.DAMN.DELICIOUS it's not even funny. This place is definitely one of my favorite sushi places, hands down!
author: Jenny L.

description: Of the trendy Marina sushi spots (Ace Wasabi, Mas Sake), Naked Fish has the best sushi. The space is sleek and modern and more comfortable and quieter (even with the tunes) than the other two, but still very cool. A sushi bar up front and restaurant seating in the back. The lobster tail is sublime.
author: Patrick B.

description: I enjoyed my dining experience here. Some friends and I decided to escape the craziness that was Fisherman's Wharf before the July 4th fireworks. So, we ended up looking for a restaurant to go for dinner because we parked on Chestnut Street. We walked down the street looking for potential places to dine and the Happy Hour sign outside caught my eye. I always enjoy Japanese food and it sounded like a good place to try especially if they have HH every day. I got a selection of rolls and gyoza to share. I especially liked the spicy hamachi rolls and "Show me the Money" which was seaweed salad over spicy scallop rolls. I would be back if I was in the Marina again.
author: Lisa M.

description: Naked Fish is the only sushi joint within walking distance that is open on Sunday nights. Which is, unfortunately, when the sushi crave hits. Happy hour is pretty poor (good prices, but not the best fish). After happy hour the rolls and portions are a little larger. The service is TERRIBLE. They can not manage to bring everyone's food at once, you have to flag down your waitress to order and to pay, and you always will get someone else's order on their first delivery attempt. Food is decent and the prices are okay.
author: Beth M.

description: Fun fusion-style sushi place in the Marina.  Ate and drank merrily at Naked Fish with a largish group of coworkers - the restaurant was able to accommodate 8 of us with relatively short notice.  This is the sort of sushi joint where you can do sake bombs without getting menacing looks from the staff or fellow diners.  This is *not* the sort of place where you go for a quiet, romantic dinner or an authentic Japanese meal.  Nevertheless, I thought that the food was a couple of notches above average, and I especially enjoyed the sake and hamachi sashimi and the firecracker balls.  I did not pay for the meal, so my rating may be slightly inflated because of it.
author: Grace W.

description: Admittedly, we came here on the 4th of July when many places are closed.   The wait to be seated was chaotic - they took down some peoples names, but not others.  Sure seemed like folks who arrived after us were seated before.   When we tried to ask about that, staff was dismissive.  Food came out in odd order and we had to follow up on order of sake that hadn't arrived by the time most of the food was on the table.   Waiting for credit card statement to arrive took forever.   And all of this would have been tolerable if the food rocked - but it didn't.   The veggie goza were bland.   The Autumn roll looked unappealing and didn't taste much better.  Shrimp tempura was good.  Perhaps just an off night, but I have no plans to return to find out.
author: Dara P.

description: So this review is just based on the lunch I had there a couple of days ago.  They actually have a really great deal when it comes to their lunch menu.  For about $8 you can choose two out of about 8 to 10 (?) options which includes miso soup, salad and rice.  That's what the other 2 in my party opted for, and the bento box type meal looked like it was a decent size, enough for two boys anyway.  I had the tempura udon which came with gyoza.  The tempura was probably the best part of it.  The udon and broth weren't that great, and I really didn't like the gyoza either.  It wasn't that flavorful, but the meal was plentiful for a lunch portion.  Price is based on lunch, and I guess you COULD get away with under $10 a person if you're a not so great tipper (boooo).  I will have to go back and judge the sashimi and sushi at a later time. Stay tuned for an update....
author: Jen T.

description: Ok, I know, we all hate the Marina.  But I went here with a group of friends for my birthday-and I loved it! At first I wasn't impressed by the front bar area with the tv playing sports (I was hoping for something a little fancier) and the fact that despite my reservation, we had to wait for 15 minutes or so. But the food was excellent, I had the dragon roll (shrimp wrapped with eel and avocado) and the seared ahi.  I'm salivating just thinking about it, I want to go back right now....Prices were reasonable, waitress was friendly. I'm pretty surprised by the low reviews....this always makes me feel like my palate must be that of a 5 year's old, if I like food that everyone hates. Oh well.
author: Jenna W.

description: Somehow the contemporary chic look and the friendly service just could not make up for the mediocre sushi.  I mean, the sushi wasn't bad.  But lately, I just don't feel like settling for something less than what I want.  Substance would be nice.
author: Shirley F.

description: Sweet happy hour. It's been awhile since I hit it up, but I do remember leaving with only $20 spent and was full of sushi and beers. I suggest show me the money, firecracker balls and spicy tuna. When I first moved to the city I thought this place was unbelievable, but as my sushi eating progressed I realized that it's not bad but it's not the BEST. It's worth a trip though. They have some unique rolls that are tasty.
author: Jen B.

description: Great quality sushi and best happy hour i've ever been to.
author: Bret A.

description:
being a sushi snob i have a hard time rating this place any better than three stars. ideally id rank it 2.5 stars. its good for what it is, a loud music, trendy small joint in nice caucasianville right off of 'i pay too much for tiny plates' blvd. 

dont get me wrong, the foods not that bad and the cocktails were 'inventive' ... but nothing to get too excited about.

id say very good first date place. loud enough to cover up akward moments, dark enough not to notice youre dates old enough to be your mom and the foods good. 

would i go? probably not.
author: Euge L.

description:
crab salad with mango, wrapped in cucumber, drizzled with mango wasabi sauce and topped with caviar.  

I can't stop thinking about this roll.  Please take me back!!
author: Zuzzi E.

description: We went with a big group and everything seemed pretty good but what you will find anywhere in sf really. What really stood out were the fire cracker balls, deep fried tuna roll with a great sauce. I am all about raw and good quality sushi but i tried one and was convinced! If you are already in the marina and want sushi give it a try.
author: Barbara C.

description: happy hour here from 4:30-6:30 is bomb! cheap rolls (but does not skimp on the quality) and the beef short ribs are the winner .... of all time beef short ribs...... mouth watering mmmmmmmm
author: Ani K.

description:
This place is absolutely terrible.  Suckered by the t.v. at the bar, because I wanted to have a light dinner while watching a Phoenix-LA playoff game, I walked in on a whim.  They have a well-positioned flat screen t.v. at the bar and the sushi chef is generous. That's the only two nice things I have to say about this place.

The bad: the green tea is overwhelmed by a brown rice and soapy flavor, the poke flavoring not only tastes store bought, but all kinds of wrong, the sushi while fresh and cut neatly is fine, but one should expect more from a sushi restaurant in San Francisco.  In fact, before going to Naked Fish, I could always say "I've never been to a bad sushi restaurant in SF," and now I say "screw you Naked Fish for that making a caveat."

Lastly, the service was terrible.  The host was glib to the point of insulting, the general attention given by the wait staff (aside from the sushi chef) was inattentive or impolite, and all this annoyed me to the point of not even watching the basketball game.

If you do go, there are a lot of alternatives, even in the same area: zushi puzzle and ace wasabi for examples. But if you do go, because everywhere else is rightfully busy- stay away from the tea, any specialities i.e. poke, rolls, etc. and stick with your basic sushi standards.
author: John L.

description: Tasty sushi, decent prices - certainly not the best sushi restaurant ever, but the ambience is good, and their sake list is pretty solid.  Overall, a solid "C".
author: Shannon W.
